title: must get back to work infection low
story: Orders have collapsed at  per cent of UK manufacturers. Our prospects worsen by the day. Restarting our economy could not be more urgent.But the Government can hardly be shockedmany are now too nervous to hurry back.For weeks it has rightly insisted we save lives by staying at home, emphasising we are all at risk.And the PM himself almost died.Turning the public’s mindset around will be daunting.But strict social ­distancing in workplaces and the ­widespread use of masks, eventheir protective effect is limited, will help provide more confidence.And statistically your chances of dying from Covid- remain minuscule. Those who have recovered from it vastly ­outnumber those who have not.The public, which backs the lockdown to a surprising degree, needs to fully grasp what’s at stake.Too many assume that the State can afford to pay them to stay home until the coast is completely clear — and that restarting the economy is about doing corporations a favour at the expense of workers’ safety. Both are nonsense.The lockdown is costing billions a day which we will all pay for. And a healthy economy is essential to our way of le and to fund every public service, above all the NHS we are all so proud of.If deaths keep falling and the infection rate stays low, we MUST get back to work.WE have to hand it to Matt Hancock.The Sun didn’t believe he’d get near , Covid tests a day. Getting to , is a fantastic feat, evena few have not yet been completed.Hancock’s team have rapidly established a huge test capacity which, combined with falling infections, is vital to unleash the “contact tracing” strategy to eventually help control the disease.It also allows those testing negative to safelyto work.Congratulations, then, Health Secretary.But so many more problems now need urgent action. title: douglas murray we need to make china pay
story: JUST one trouble with conspiracies is that they sometimes turn out to be true. Especially when you are dealing with a government like China’s.As viewers of the series Chernobyl know, non-democratic governments have a history of covering up their errors.In that case, the Soviets did everything they could to stop the world learning about the meltdown at their nuclear reactor.Today the Communist Party of China has done everything it can to hide what happened in Wuhan. Especially the origins of the disease which has shut down the world.Yesterday President Trump broke one of the taboos in all this. Which is needed.The question is: What is the likelihood the coronavirus originated in the exact part of China that has a laboratory looking into just such viruses To date the Chinese authorities have allowed the world to believe in the bat-eating, wet-market theory on the origins of the epidemic.They prefer embarrassment over suspicion.But all along, people have wondered whether something less “accidental” is at play.Now the US President has told reporters he has seen strong evidence that Covid- originated from the laboratory in Wuhan. The President’s remarks change the game.China should be in enough trouble as it is. Evenit was true that the virus is an accident caused by a strange food custom, the Chinese Communist Party has a lot to answer for.Why did it keep the news of the virus to itself for so many weeks  Why did it pretend it is not lethal as we now know it is Or pretend that it was hard to transmit  Why did they refuse to allow in inspectors from the World Health Organisation And why have the WHO now been refused inclusion in China’s own investigation into the origins of Covid- Questions also remain over the WHO’s seeming collusion with China over the crisis.The CCP’s actions would be bad enoughthe virus came from a wet market. But it must know that it is in a whole dferent realm of troublethe virus turns out to have come from its lab.If the CCP knew all along the virus had leaked from there then its cover-up is even more appalling. Because it means they knew exactly what they — and soon the world — were dealing with.But in the absence of trust-worthy information, darker and wilder theories take shape in the shadows. For example, could the virus have come from the Wuhan lab and been released deliberately To those deeply skeptical of the CCP, it’s not hard to believe it might have done that.They are in a trade war with America with a President who was making them lose. Now the CCP has managed to shut down the entire US economy with a virus.The question for the rest of the world will soon be simple: What to do about this There are several steps. The first is to try to determine exactly how this virus came about. To have an international  look into every possible cause. With no area of inquiry ruled out.That  should also investigate how the communist regime lied their way through this virus. We need to learn just how they managed to make a local problem into a global one.Then there is the question of what price they should pay. For accidental or not, there is no way that the CCP should be allowed to get away with this.Goodness knows they have tried. Throughout this crisis there have been a set of PR gestures by the Chinese authorities.The government and government-linked firms such as Huawei have made a big show of donating masks and other equipment.It is dismal. Like watching somebody who has just burned down your house offering you a watering can.Last month, German newspaper Bild infuriated China by suggesting Beijing should pay reparations for the coronavirus pandemic.It printed an “invoice’ for nearly billion eurosleading the Chinese embassy in Berlin to accuse the paper of stirring up prejudice.But once the engine of the other global economies — including ours — roars back into motion, we must make China pay.We must re-think our relationship with them. We should recognise the country is not just a competitor but a liability.We must punish them for the large-scale theft of information from British and American businesses it has engaged in for years.We must do whatever we can to disrupt their “belt-and-road” empire-building, which the CCP has worked its way into, and “bought up” small and poor countries.But it is not only such countries that are at the mercy of China and its President Xi Jinping. We may be in Britain too.Before this Wuhan disaster kicked off, our Government approved Huawei to provide part of our G capability.All of our allies warned against this. Our intelligence-sharing partners in the Five Eyes networkall strongly warned the British Government against allowing a firm that is indistinguishable from the CCP from having such access.Experience shows Chinese firms cannot be trusted to provide such sensitive — and strategic — technology.The Huawei decision was a rare misstep by the Johnson government. Now is the time to correct it.We do not need to provoke China. But nor do we need to pander to it. And we should not be putting our future security in their hands.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Trade sanctions may be the only way to make the CCP understand just how much damage it has done to the UK and global economy.Whatever the origins of this virus, we must show China that there is a cost to lying on this scale.A cost to causing the whole world to be locked in our homes. title: instagram celebs boasting lockdown
story: THIS week, the actor Chris Hemsworth was photographed with his agreeable-looking child, in the sunshine, outside their beachfront home in the exclusive Australian surfing resort of Byron Bay.And I guess everyone thought when they saw the picture: “Well, lockdown’s working pretty well for him.”Yeah, and it can’t be too bad either for Mrs Hemsworth. Living by the sea, in paradise, with a triangular- torsoed Hollywood hunk.But thenyou take a glance at your social media, you’ll notice that absolutely everyone  is living the Hemsworth dream.It’s an endless parade of people’s perfect sourdough baking and of jolly board games with the kids.This morning, my Instagram feed featured a young family doing a fancy dress dinner, a girl on an enormous horse, a woman sprawled on the bonnet of a Mercedes SL, a man with a cute dog, doing exercises, and a shot of some cows taken through a wisteria bush.On Instagram, no one is ever bored, it never rains and everyone’s breasts are perfect. Especially Chris Hemsworth’s.This is having an effect on the nation’s teenagers. They have been told there will be no exams this year and that all their school work was for nothing. They’ve been told they have to stay indoors and that they can’t see their friends.And it’s driving them mad because they do not read newspapers. They do not listen to the BBC news. And they replaced Radio  with Spoty five years ago.This means they never hear any actual news. So they don’t know what’s going on.Instead they look at their phonesand all they can see are pretty girls with swimsuits up their a*** cheeks, and Chris Hemsworth, and parents who have turned the cellar into a nightclub and lots of cute ducklings.And they’re thinking, as they watch the rain trickle down the windows at their house: “Why can’t I have some of that ”But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.In the olden days we’d have smacked their bottoms and told them to stop being spoiled, but that’s not allowed any more. So I’ve come up with another idea . . .If you are an old person stuck in a tower block, waiting for Covid- to stick its warty little head through the letterbox, post a picture of your surroundings on Instagram. Don’t hold back. Show us the overflowing cat litter and the photograph of your husband, alone in his hospital bed.Show us also pictures of your sister who is in a care home and hasn’t had a visitor for five weeks.And your food cupboard which has nothing in it any more. And your empty bottle of Senokot.In fact, we should all get in on the act. Don’t wait for a joyous moment to photograph and share. Send us instead pictures of stuff you didn’t enjoy.The particularly gruesome bit of wax you’ve just pulled out of your left ear. The turd your dog just did on the mat. Your fat other half slobbing out in front of the TV.Your kids throwing Monopoly pieces at one another after a row over Fenchurch Street station.Instead of sharing your perfect loaf, send pictures of the charred wreck that went wrong, the scarf full of dropped stitches, the wonky self-assembly garden furniture that broke the first time you sat on it.Hit us with the reality of lockdown. Admit that it’s one part happiness and nine parts ditch water.And then maybe teenagers will start to understand that le is bookended by the lucky and the not so lucky. At one end you’ve got the Hemsworths. At the other you’ve got a frightened old man in a tenement block in Bermondsey.Maybe then they will understand they are somewhere in the middle, and stop bloody complaining.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.There is much debate about what increases your chances of dying from Covid-.Well, I don’t know about you but I’ve addressed the issue by sitting on a sofa for six hours a day, eating slabs of Cadbury’s Fruit  Nut chocolate and getting up only to go to the fridge for another bottle of wine.I guess I’m working on the principle that soon I’ll be so fat, there won’t be room in the house for me and the virus as well.But there is one problem.There are now so many empty bottles sitting by the bins at the bottom of the drive I just know my neighbours will assume I’ve been throwing illegal parties, and call the police.A nurse made headlines this week after moaning about the cramped conditions on a London Tube train at .am.She said she was risking her le at work and pointed out that she shouldn’t have to risk it even more while commuting. Fair point, you might think. But hang on.In the olden days – before March – people may well have been on a Tube train at that time because they were coming home from a club.But these days, nobody on a Tube train at quarter to six in the morning is there for fun. They’re ALL going to work.There’s nothing wrong with that. It’s what most of us have been told to do all along. But I do agree that commuting on a cramped Tube is bloody dangerous.So I ask once again for parking restrictions to be lted immediately, as this would allow people to go to work in the blissful self-isolation of their own cars.I WAS told this week, by The Times newspaper no less, that this summer’s must-have accessory is a straw handbag. No it isn’t.As no one’s looking and no one’s going out, this year’s must-have accessory is the pyjama bottom teamed with odd socks.An aerial photograph of Portsmouth taken this week showed that the colour of the sea has turned from the usual mud brown to a shimmering, aquamarine blue.It’s the sort of colour you usually associate with the Caribbean, and it is genuinely amazing.Naturally, green people are saying it happened because the lockdown means less traffic. And they may be right.Or, let me just lob this one in . . .  it happened because the photographer was experimenting with some of the filters on his new phone.My phone’s got so many thatyou gave me long enough, I could take a selfie and make me look like Chris Hemsworth. Or his we. A MINISTER in the South African government an ounced this week that his country has plenty of PPE for front-line health workers and that all patients with Covid- will be given “vibrators”.I think he meant “ventilators”.If he didn’t, well, I guess they’ll die happy.For the past couple of years, farmers have not been allowed to spray their bright yellow oil seed rape with insecticides called neonicotinoids.As a result, a lot of my crop is dead.But on the upside, I’m now seeing more bumble bees than I have in years. And yesterday I saw a tortoiseshell butterfly, the first I’ve found since about .But that said, my eyesight is so bad these days, it could have been an actual tortoise.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: david blunkett lockdown decisions government must make
story: Substitute the word politics for socialism and it is immediately obvious that prioritising in the coronavirus crisis poses almost impossible choices for the leadership of our country in moving to recovery.Recovery not just for our economy, but also for our social well-being and the normalisation of everyday le which makes living worthwhile.This week Boris Johnson promised that in the coming days he would set out a menu of options for a phasedto some form of normality in the weeks ahead.But the balance between lting the lockdown too quickly and failing to appreciate the long-term detrimental impact on every aspect of our lives, of the delay in ing to near normality, requires the wisdom of Solomon.Almost  years ago, when I became Home Secretary, Islamist terrorists launched their attack on the World Trade Center in New York.Almost , people lost their lives in one day and the immediate expectation was that there would be an attack here in the UK, most probably in London.When we met as a Cabinet, decisions had to be taken immediately as to whether to lock down the capital in the anticipation that lives might be lost in the days ahead.Steady nerves prevailed as we realised that the damage we would do to ourselves would be far greater than that which might be inflicted by our enemies.That is why, with our hearts in our mouths, we encouraged people to go to work and continue their lives as normal while taking every possible step behind the scenes to put in measures to protect us from attack.The virus is very dferent and the choices to be made are more dficult.Distancing and social isolation were clearly the right measure to put in place six weeks ago to reduce the transmission of infection, the pressure on the NHS and, above all, the loss of le.Whether or not the organised supply of PPE and the rapid expansion of testing was a failure of government is for another day — but what isn’t is the careful steps needed to get us out of this lockdown.Because while opinion polling shows not only public support for caution, but also anxiety about ing to work and social contact, the potential irreparable damage to our economy will hurt all of us.The job of politicians is to hear but then to balance alternative conclusions from the experts — as Winston Churchill put it: “Scientists should be on tap, but not on top.”In our democracy, leaders need to gain consent but they also have to assess and take risks. If the current measures start to erode, unforeseen dangers could arise.Yet, move too quickly and you risk being blamed for getting it wrong.In some form continuing to isolate without isolation will be necessary, but avoiding great damage to the most disadvantaged children, many of whom are receiving no schooling at all, is vital for our future.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Equally, preventing the potential shortening of the lives of older people through continuing inactivity and lack of social contact must form part of the equation.In the end it isn’t those appearing on TV and radio, often with contradictory analysis and advice, but elected politicians who must do the right thing.Carefully, conscientiously but bravely they must now lead us out of the unsustainable lockdown which, while necessary at the time, could,prolonged, be a more damaging medicine than the original disease.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus women equal leadership
story: AS I have often pointed out, there are many reasons why women make good leaders.In my experience, they tend to be good collaborators because their ego is unlikely to interfere with letting other people have good ideas, and be able to voice them and take credit for them.Their emotional intelligence and empathy makes them excellent communicators.But it’s not just my view that women are good leaders. Many studies show women are more focused on building community and teams.They are more likely than men to cultivate a erse set of advisers to help them succeed. They are also more likely to follow advice.A study by management consulting firm McKinsey found that women are more people- orientated and spend more time developing and coaching other leaders in their organisation. In other words, they don’t need to reserve all the glory for themselves.There is something  at play too, though. Female leaders are more likely to be blameddecisions are unpopular or ineffective. They are questioned and second-guessed more often than men.But then Covid- entered the equation and presented world leaders with a new challenge — an invisible enemy that is highly contagious, unpredictable and deadly.This pandemic has been an unprecedented test for all concerned.And guess what  A disproportionate number of those who have passed this test — countries such as Germany, New Zealand, Iceland and Finland — have women at the helm.It is not exclusively female-led countries that are doing well, of course. But bearing in mind only seven per cent of all world leaders are women, about  per cent of countries led by women are doing well when it comes to containing Covid-. Global health experts have concluded that one thing that has led to success in tackling coronavirus is — speed.Prof Tom Bollyky, director of global health programme at US think-tank the Council on Foreign Relations, said: “Countries that have not dithered in their response, that have mobilised quickly, have done well.”New Zealand’s PM Jacinda Ardern put it simply: “Go hard and go early.”The number of Covid--related deaths is predicted to be substantially lower in areas where leaders acted sooner, even by a week, because they flattened the curve and prevented new cases.Many women acted first and made the brave decision to shut down le as we knew it, even though that was an unpopular thing to do.But it seems women leaders are listening to World Health Organisation advice and also looking at other countries for guidance.They don’t think they have all the answers but women are able to put their ego to one side and let experts guide them — something which cannot be said of Donald Trump.Incidentally, I have not seen any women leaders making unfounded or dangerous suggestions about possible cures. Can you imagine a woman leader suggesting that people inject Dettol into themselves, as dingbat Trump recently suggested Or can you imagine a woman suggesting to people that they can fight coronavirus and winthey are strong enough This pandemic is not a battle to be fought and won. It is a virus, which can affect literally anyone.No one knows how they will be affected and that bullish “fight it” approach is, in my experience, very male. Conversely, the decision to protect everyone, putting the most at risk first, is more female.It’s interesting that some male leaders seem more interested in covering up the problems. Like Donald Trump, who thinks he is an expert on everything and more fixated on garnering praise for what he has done than fixing and getting right what has not gone so well.I know I am talking in generalisations here but my experience of women is that we want to understand the mistakes and fix them, not cover them up.This pandemic has been full of dficulty and tragedy for everyone.But perhaps one good thing that will come out of it is that the world will acknowledge women deserve an equal  when it comes to leadership.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.FORMER Love Islander Montana Brown this week posted some “Instagram vs reality” pictures ­– one of her in a lacy bralette and silky shorts, the other in a cute pink PJ set.But I couldn’t help but notice that she is wearing  eyelashes and full make-up in bed – in both sets.The very idea of wearing make-up, let alone  eyelashes at the moment, is unimaginable – especially to go to sleep.A far more realistic picture of my le at present, in fact, is that I am mainly wearing pyjamas all day as well as in bed.HAS anyone  been watching Madonna’s “Quarantine Diaries” on Instagram This week she said she has coronavirus antibodies, having been tested for the virus.And her conclusion in the face of this discovery  “Tomorrow, I’m going to go for a long drive in a car and I’m going to roll down the window, and I’m going to breathe in the Covid- air,” she says.Sorry, but what  No one knows yet whether it’s possible to have coronavirus more than once and the presence of antibodies may not provide protection against the disease.This seems like a risk no one should be advocating.The bonny baby, who has already inherited his father’s hair, was named after both their grandfathers and the doctor who saved Boris’s le.A wonderful and touching gesture.Wilfred, a name not popular since the s, takes its roots from “will” and “peace”, two words very apt for these dficult times.HUGE congratulations to Gigi Hadid and Zayn Malik, who confirmed this week they are expecting a baby.I guess the lockdown baby boom has already started, which just proves that le goes on.What a beautul baby they will have.It’s great to have some good news amid the gloom.WHAT a month it’s been for Boris Johnson.For the past few weeks he has faced professional challenges far bigger than those he may have anticipated when he was first elected Prime Minister.Not only that, but he has also survived time in intensive care suffering from coronavirus. And now he is a father yet again at .I think it’s fair to say that this period will go down in his own personal history as perhaps some of the most memorable few weeks of his le.EVEN the most hardened climate change denier cannot fail to pause for thought at the before and after photos of the Solent.Aerial shots of this part of Britain’s coastline look more like pictures that have been taken in the Caribbean.The water is so blue and so clean that it looks positively tropical. In fact, it’s unrecognisable after just six weeks of lockdown.The images show how the usually murky waters of the UK coastline have been transformed, which must surely be due in part to a reduction in pollution since the coronavirus pandemic stopped leisure traffic on the Solent.But other astonishing photos from all over the world have surfaced recently too.Pollution-free images of landmarks in Delhi and Beijing, which are all too often seen shimmering under a haze of smog, are a real reminder of our role in creating pollution and also in reducing it.Imagineanother silver lining to this terrible pandemic was that we all began to understand the effects of our impact on the environment, and that we took the threat of climate change more seriously – and started to take responsibility for changing our ways.I AM as keen as the next person to regain my freedom, and for things to begin toto normal.But I cannot be the only one who gave a shudder at the thought of being allowed to choose a “bubble” of just ten family members as friends, as was hinted at by some.Can you even imagine the disputes, upsets and hurt feelings that would result all over the landyour chosen bubble had chosen another group to huddle with In fact, that rule would likely cause so much offence that we would only have ten friends left. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kfc delivery drivers ignore coronavirus social distancing
story: KFC has launched an investigation after delivery drivers ignored social distancing measures and packed together to pick up orders.  Pictures show workers gathered outside a newly opened restaurant in Filton, Bristol, despite the coronvairus rules.Hundreds of KFC restaurants have reopened across the UK to deliver food during the lockdown, with social distancing measures introduced in stores to keep staff and customers safe.They include keeping people two metres apart and involve a contactless handover of food.Pictures sent to Bristol Live, however, show delivery riders flouting the measures, bunched close together as they waited to pick up orders.A KFC spokesperson told Sun Online: “We’ve introduced new measures to make sure we’re reopening responsibly for both our team members and delivery drivers.These include stickers on the floor and clear signage to help delivery drivers follow social distancing guidance, as well as contactless handover of food.Its nice to see how much weve been missed - and we’re grateful to our teams for working hard to keep up with demand!We’re looking into what’s happened at our Filton restaurant and our delivery partners are following up with their drivers in the area to remind them of these new processes.”It is unclear who the delivery drivers worked for but there is a Deliveroo sticker on the restaurants door.At Deliveroo, as part of the riders Supplier Agreement, riders must comply with companys safety standards.If riders are found not to be abiding public health measures, they could lose their account.Riders for Uber Eats and Just Eat also deliver for KFC.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: uk weather forecast today heat
story: The sunshine is expected to stick around on Sunday, reaching C across much of the country.After a week of drizzle and gloom in lockdown, the UK has basked in some light relief today.The low pressure which has dumped torrential rain on much of the country this week has been forecast to move across Europe.And as the UK spends its sixth weekend in lockdown due to the coronavirus pandemic, weather conditions are expected to be much more settled thanks to building high pressure.According to The Met Office, the change will result in “dry, fine and settled weather” this weekend and particularly next week.Saturday was warm with a high of C felt by most of the country.Further dry, fine and settled weather is expected on Sunday, with potential for very light winds - however most places will enjoy “dry and decent weather.”SundayThe Met Office predict most of the country will see sunny intervals, however some rain could fall in northern and eastern parts of the nation.For most of the country, a high of C will be felt, and a low of C.Monday to WednesdayMainly dry, sunny spells developing, few showers in Eastern England on Monday. Mainly dry, sunny spells in most places, but heavy showers in SW Tuesday. Dry and sunny on Wednesday.On Sunday, cloudier conditions are expected in the south and southwest with perhaps some light rain or drizzle in the far southwest.Some parts of the east coast will feel more of a chill in the air.The high pressure will remain in charge for most of next week, meaning the warm sunny weather is here to stay for at least a few more days.The Met Office warns that while the weather change will tempt many across the country to spend their weekend outdoors, the UK must continue to adhere to the coronavirus lockdown.Simon Partridge encouraged people to enjoy the sunshine from their backyards, balconies and daily hour-long walks - though he did add that UV levels will be reasonably high over the weekend, so people must cover up accordingly.The high pressure build won’t last forever, and is expected to move on by the following weekend and bring with it more wet and miserable weather.Ministers will be hoping the resurgence of sunshine will not encourage Brits to venture outside of their homes and break lockdown rules as has been seen in the past few weeks.For the beginning of next week, the weather still appears to be setting with the occasional shower in Eastern England on Monday ad heavy showers in the southwest on Tuesday.Generally the UK will remain dry with some sunny spells, particularly on Wednesday.The sunshine comes after Britain experienced as much rain in a day as it did for the rest of April two days ago.The Met Office is now predicting settled, warmer weather for the beginning of the month, although we can still expect some showers, and itll be much cooler than last week.Aprils sunshine was caused by a high pressure system from the continent - but recently weve faced the opposite, with low pressure systems bringing in colder weather and lots of rain.

title: madeleine mccann parents haunted 13 years lockdown
story: Kate and Gerry McCann were due to mark the anniversary of their daughters disappearance with a prayer gathering on Sunday, but lockdown measures mean they will hold an online service instead.Sharing a message online, Kate and Gerry likened Maddie’s experience to victims hit by the Covid- crisis - fear, hurt and loneliness.They wrote: There will be many vulnerable people whose situation will have become even more precarious in the current lockdown conditions, with fear, worry and isolation - emotions that we dreaded Madeleine experiencing and which haunted us for a long time - and still do on occasions.Our thoughts and prayers are with all those suffering at this time.Heart doctor Gerry, , and ex GP turned medical worker Kate, , were forced to axe the annual service they hold in memory of Maddie for the first time this year.But are still urging local villagers and well-wishers to come together remotely to mark the poignant occasion.The family are due to share prayers and readings online as they spend the anniversary behind closed doors at their home in Rothley, Leics.Writing on the Find Maddie and Facebook Campaign websites, they said: It is now  years since we were last with Madeleine.Her th birthday is to follow in the next couple of weeks - the latter tangibly, painfully, bringing it home to us what we have missed and continue to miss as a family.“I dont think any of us could have predicted the situation we all find ourselves in currently.It shows how easy it is to become complacent with our lives and circumstances, albeit a totally normal and understandable, human characteristic.Alongside an iconic photo of Maddie, they wrote: We have been fortunate to spend more time together as a family since lockdown began, an enforced block to a usually frenetic le, a silver lining to this dark cloud.It has made us think about Madeleine even more, as she would have shared this period of special closeness with us too.”It comes as Scotland Yard vows to continue the search for Maddie with renewed funds expected to be approved by the Home Office.Kate and Gerry added: The investigation to find Madeleine remains open and continues, even though, in a way dferent to the ideal.We remain grateful for the ongoing efforts and commitment from all those involved in the search to find her and we hope and pray, as always, that our efforts will be fruitful.”Thanking those who have supported them, the McCann’s said: Thank you to everyone still offering their support and good wishes for Madeleine and ourselves.Such solidarity continues to strengthen us. Thank you.Please take care and please spare a thought or prayer for Madeleine and all missing children this weekend.Heres hoping that more normal, safe and happy times are close at hand.Three-year-old Maddie vanished from a holiday apartment in Portugal’s Praia da Luz on May , .She had been left sleeping alone with her younger twin siblings while her parents were dining in a nearby tapas restaurant with pals.Her family cling on to a glimmer of hope she could still be alive.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: british airways staff not laid off to sign zero hour contract
story: BRITISH Airways wants its entire workforce to sign up to new contracts which would allow them to lay-off staff without negotiation.Union leaders fear the “traumatised” workforce is being railroaded into accepting the equivalent of zero-hour deals which could be ripped-up in the event of turbulence in future.Details emerged last night as The Sun was leaked a breakdown of job-losses at British Airways - with  engineers among those getting the boot.Yesterday union chiefs submitted legal papers to the High Court to argue that BA’s bid to make , staff redundant is illegal.They say the -day consultation period should in fact be  days.Leaders blasted the airline for jettisoning staff when BA parent company IAG was sitting on £.billion in its coffers.Airline insiders said the mooted June  deadline is in fact the earliest a deal could be reached, with the likelihood being staff issues are resolved by December.Workers given the boot will be offered standard statutory redundancy plus three months wages.A BA insider said: “A negotiating process is under way. Everything is up for grabs. The airline is fighting for survival.”The Sun was shown BA’s predicted job loss breakdown - with , flight crew getting the boot.Also leaving BA are , from head office,  engineers,  contact centre staff, , Heathrow ground staff and  Gatwick ground staff.The projected job loss total is ,.BA was yesterday accused of “dirty tricks” and faced a furious backlash over controversial plans to axe staff after using taxpayer cash to furlough its workforce.Five MPs near Heathrow airport wrote an angry letter to BA boss Alex Cruz asking for an urgent meeting to explain himself.The letter, penned by Seema Malhotra, MP for Feltham  Heston, said: “We would urge you to work with unions and government to do everything possible to find a solution and mitigate job losses.“We would greatly appreciateyou could urgently meet with us to provide a briefing on steps you are taking to alleviate the immediate financial pressures and reduce the number of jobs which could be cut, the extent to which government schemes are assisting with the impact and the support you will be providing to those who lose their jobs.”The cross-party letter was signed by Ruth Cadbury, MP for Brentford and Isleworth, John McDonnell MP for Hayes and Harlington, Virendra Sharma MP for Ealing and Southall, and James Murray MP for Ealing North.Another - MP, Tory Andrew Grfiths representing Burton - wrote to constituents accusing BA of “dirty tricks” and a huge “over-reaction”.He said: “If I was a cynic I would speculate that BA has done this precisely in the hope that everyone lobbies their MP and that they got more government bail-out money as the result.”Unite yesterday told BA staff: “BA has availed itself of millions of pounds of taxpayers money, ostensibly to avoid making staff redundant.“But they have not honoured that commitment or the spirit for which it was intended.“In fact it would appear that BA has simply sought to take advantage of staff being furloughed and dismiss them in their absence.”The unions said BAs behaviour was “both legally and morally” wrong.Swathes of furious cabin crew yesterday boycotted an online chat with BA’s cabin crew boss Amy James.Pilots union Balpa said it was “hugely disappointed” with BA for its “opportunism”.In a scathing response to BA’s plans, Balpa said the airline was “in breach” of Covid emergency plans: “The main purpose of the government Job Retention Scheme is to avoid the need for any compulsory redundancies.”BA was accused by the pilots’ bosses of trying to “exploit” the coronavirus pandemic.The Sun told first how BA had furloughed around , staff amid the coronavirus shutdown.BA bosses plan to ditch its Worldwide, Eurofleet and Mixed cabin fleets to create a single new crew team at Heathrow, serving long-haul and short-haul flights.The Sun told yesterday how BA could stop all flights from the UK’s biggest airport Heathrow - and may decide never toto the second largest hub Gatwick.BA’s redundancy plans and talks with the union were put on hold when coronavirus struck, decimating the airline industry.Insiders said strike action could follow because “BA staff are traumatised and have nothing left to lose”.A spokesman for BA said: “We can’t comment further while we consult with our unions”

title: kate middleton virtual visit parents
story: Kate, , cooed over newborns in a video call to parents and midwives coping with hospital births during the coronavirus crisis.The duchess, a mum-of-three, gushed over -hours-old baby boy Max on the call to Kingston Hospital’s Maternity Unit.She spent two days on a work placement at the hospital, in south London, last November.Speaking on video link due to coronavirus restrictions she joked with mum Rebecca Attwood and dad John Gill, of London.She said: “This is definitely a first, I think.”And added: “Well firstly, huge congratulations. Is it a little boy or a little girl ”Rebecca, who sat beside her son’s cot, said: “It’s a little boy.”Given a closer look at little Max, the Duchess said: “He is so sweet. Ah, congratulations! When did you have him ”Told he had arrived at pm the previous night, the future queen replied: “My goodness, you must be exhausted.”Rebecca replied: “Yep. I’m pretty tired now.”The new mum, from South West London, said: Having a surprise conversation with the Duchess of Cambridge after two hours sleep was particularly surreal.The Duchess asked us about having a baby at such an unusual time, and our experience on the maternity ward was that all the midwives made it as normal as possible – apart from the masks!Midwives wearing PPE described how staff were coping with anxious mums facing going into labour during the pandemic.Jo Doumouchtsi, Perinatal Mental Health Midwe, said: “The main issues that women are having at the moment really are around coming into hospital and worries about catching Covid, but also about the isolation after the baby is born.“They have to self-isolate, so they are having limited support from their other family members.“We are finding that there’s women that have no mental health history that are actually becoming incredibly anxious because of the situation currently.“So we’re having a lot more referrals which are specically around anxiety to do with Covid.”A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.The duchess also held talks with midwives at the hospital over a zoom video call.She spoke about the need for NHS staff to get help they need as they deal with coronavirus.Kate said: “We’ve heard it with the frontline workers, for those who are struggling, they don’t feel they can reach out because they feel guilty for doing it, which is extraordinary to hear.“With new mums and parents and families, they don’t want to feel like they’re overburdening, but it is so important to reach out and ask for help when you do need it.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. whether it’s on the phone, through social media, in any form actually -you have got access to it, it does provide that normality and normalising of some of these anxieties and these worries.”Her virtual visit was held ahead of Maternal Mental Health Awareness Week starting tomorrow.The royal couple regularly visited the award-winning White Eagle in Rhoscolyn in Anglesey, North Wales, while William was stationed in the area working as a search and rescue helicopter pilot.During the three years he was based at RAF Valley, they would often tuck into a traditional pub lunch, with William opting for burger and chips and Kate ordering fish and salad.But it’s now been revealed the haunt has gone bust after suffering harsh losses due to coronavirus.Sarah O’Toole and Jason Bell of Grant Thornton UK have been appointed joint administrators of  venues, including the White Eagle.Sarah said: “We are hopeful we can find a buyer for the businesses despite the current challenges facing the pub and hospitality sector.During the couple’s time in Anglesey, a member of staff revealed: “They’re just like any other young couple in love – until you realise they’ve got armed bodyguards on the next table.Prince William drinks bitter, perhaps a pint or two, and Kate sticks to white wine and sparkling water.He seems to enjoy our home-made burgers and chips. title: shocking pics of wuhan scientists bats deleted coronavirus
story: WORRYING photographs of scientists handling bat samples have been deleted from the website of the institute blamed for the coronavirus pandemic.The images - which reveal a shocking lack of safety - were taken down by the Wuhan Institute of Virology after diplomats and scientists raised the alarm about its work.US and British intelligence officials suspect bungling scientists at the science hub spread the killer disease during risky coronavirus tests on bats.And President Donald Trump announced on Thursday he had seen intelligence that gave him a high degree of confidence that the global crisis had its origins in the institute.It was claimed that Covid- was developed in the Wuhan lab as China hoped to prove its greater than the US at battling deadly diseases.The Sun has already revealed a page of the Wuhan institute’s website - deleted suddenly last month - showed no safety precautions were employed.One worker admitted being sprayed with bat blood or urine as images showed staff brazenly collecting samples with no face masks or protective suits.Incredibly some scientists didn’t even wear gloves as they entered caves to collect fecal bat swab samples, beaming for the camera and oblivious to the dangers.The damning photos tell a dferent story to an official  journal, when the institute insisted: Bat samplings were conducted ten times from April  to October  at dferent seasons in their natural habitat at a single locationin Kunming, Yunnan Province, China.“All members of field teams wore appropriate personal protective equipment, including N masks, tear-resistant gloves, disposable outerwear, and safety glasses.“Bats were trapped and fecal swab samples were collected as described previously.”One of the party even gave an interview to state-run news agency Xinhua, admitting he forgot his protective gear and was sprayed with bat urine or blood.Intelligence sources in the US and UK were “monitoring the deleted photos with great interest”, The Sun was told.Matthew Henderson, director of the Asia Studies Centre at the Henry Jackson Society, and a former British diplomat in China, told The Sun: China has still not clearly explained how the outbreak started, without it we are obliged to draw our own conclusions.“There is ample evidence of such a cavalier approach to biosecurity by Chinese scientists based in Wuhan laboratories that it is no surprise that western Governments are now seriously considering whether COVID- could have escaped from one.Earlier this month photos from the same Wuhan lab showed a broken seal on a store containing , virus strains - including the bat coronavirus linked to the devastating pandemic.The images were published by the state-owned China Daily before they too were swtly deleted.A picture of the fridge-freezer revealed a flimsy loose seal on the door, as a lab worker pulled out a chilled box containing deadly samples while wearing gloves and a mask.Several insiders claimed the deadly bug wasnt manufactured as a bioweapon but to prove China was on par with - story: SOCIAL bubbles could be limited to just  people until next year as weddings and birthdays are “super-spreader” events, scientists have warned.Scientists have found large family events are among the deadliest ways to spread coronavirus.They claim gatherings of between  and  people allow one person carrying Covid- to infect up to  others.Senior epidemiologist Adam Kucharski said Britain faces “exponential growth” and risks “being back where we started” once lockdown measures are lted.He told The Sunday Times: “Look at where these super-spreading events occur, its often at family gatherings and meals and weddings and parties and all these things that socially we want to happen.“As soon as measures are lted, we risk being back where we started, facing exponential growth.”Dr Kucharski, a senior epidemiologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said these gatherings could pose a threat well into .He added: “These kinds of meals and gatherings and parties of  to  people seem to come up again and again in the data.“We are seeing  or so people getting infected [by one person] instead of the usual reproduction number, which is about two or three.”Celebrations such as birthdays, office parties and Christmas dos may have to have restrictions later this year.But it isn’t all doom and gloom. Research shows that outdoor activies, such as visiting parks and possibly non-contact sports, seem to be low-risk.Dr Kucharski added: “The hope is that new measures can give us as much freedom as possible.“But, we’re going to have to have some form of social distancing in place for a long time.”Meanwhile, a study by the Division of Molecular and Clinical Medicineat the University of Dundee, found social groups should be limited to five people.They told The Sunday : “Lockdown can barely contain the disease’s spread.“Brits will have to substantially reduce their normal level of social interaction to ensure the number of cases doesnt start to rise out of control.“Our data is more consistent with a need to adopting a ‘new normal’ that can provide the optimal balance between allowing economic activity while ensuring very substantial reductions in prior social contacts -  per cent reductions according to our best estimates.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: paramedic vandals car oldham manchester
story: John Lowe, , was woken up around midnight on Friday by loud banging noises outside his home in Oldham, Gtr Manchester.The medic, who works for North West Ambulance Service, opened the front door as his we and teenage son slept upstairs to find his Vauxhall Astra engulfed in flames.John checked his CCTV and was horried to see someone throwing an object at his car before it set alight.He said: You try and do the best for people and theres no reason you should be targeted for it.My we is really shaken up and scared.She hasn’t stopped crying and my son is feeling really frightened by it.Why would someone target someone who is part of the NHS or a key worker Fire crews were able to put the flames out before it reached Johns house.Fortunately, nobody was injured in the blaze although John says his car has been completely written off.Shocking pictures show the back of the vehicle completely gutted by the blaze with ash sprayed across the driveway.John added: “It easily could have set the house on fire. It doesnt bear thinking about what could have happened.It is a lovely street usually. You feel like you do your best to serve the public and everyone round here knows that I am a paramedic.I just dont understand why my family have been targeted.I am just glad I wasnt working a night sht because I dont know what I would have doneI wasnt there.Greater Manchester Police have been contacted for comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus reveals shocking rise child
story: NewsopinionCoronavirus reveals shocking rise in child poverty under Conservative rule, says Labour MPCovid- has highlighted gaping holes in social security as the number of children in poverty rises to . millionShareCommentsByKate Green MP, Labour’s Shadow Minister for Child Poverty Strategy and Margaret Greenwood, Shadow Minister for Schools:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionKate Green says children could go hungry during the pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe coronavirus lockdown is shining a light on many issues that don’t get the attention they deserve: the low levels of social security payments, the value of workers in the food and distribution sectors and the importance of valuing care workers. We must also shine a light on the lives of children in poverty. Child poverty has already risen to . million under the Conservatives. In , the IFS predicted that the figure would increase to over  million by  , a direct result of government policies including the four year freeze on working age benefits and the two-child limit - and the coronavirus pandemic threatens to see it rise even higher. Right now pressure on family budgets, especially for those in low-paid, insecure employment, are being compounded as parents lose their jobs, are furloughed or see their working hours reduced. There is real concern that children will go hungry during the pandemic, in part because of logistical problems with the rollout of the national voucher scheme that is supposed to enable children eligible for free school meals to continue to access meals while they are out of school. The government must resolve these issues and ensure that funding levels for the scheme are sufficient to provide healthy, nutritious meals for children. Sadly, many parents will be forced to go without in order to feed their children. A YouGov poll commissioned earlier this month by the Food Foundation and the Food, Farming and Countryside Commission found that . million people had gone a whole day without eating since the lockdown came into effect, and that . million people say someone in their household has had to reduce or skip meals because they could not access or afford sufficient food. Parents going without is, of course, not a solution to the problem. The government must take action to address poverty now. Labour is calling for five urgent social security measures to provide immediate support to people affected by the coronavirus crisis: all Universal Credit advances to be converted to cash grants, the abolition of the two-child limit in Universal Credit and Tax Credits, suspension of the benefit cap, removal of the savings thresholds in Universal Credit, and an increase in Jobseeker’s Allowance and Employment Support Allowance to match the increase in Universal Credit.  Teachers across the country are working hard to ensure that the nine million children who are staying at home can continue to learn. However, this will be easier for some children than others. Children living in cramped housing will find it harder to learn than their more affluent classmates children who are hungry will undoubtedly struggle and those without Internet access and a laptop, tablet or PC will again be disadvantaged. The IPPR has pointed out that ‘an estimated  million children and their families do not have adequate access to a device or connectivity at home’. While the government has recently announced a scheme to provide digital devices and G dongles, to help some disadvantaged Year  pupils, care leavers and school children with social workers who do not already have such devices and who do not have access to the Internet, this has already met with delays and we still need clarity as to which children will benefit.Read more about our  Give Me Five campaign Poverty can have a devastating impact on children’s lives and on their futures. According to The Children’s Society, children growing up in poverty are more likely to experience mental health problems, under-achieve in school, feel unsafe and be subjected to bullying. They are also more likely to feel like a failure. It is vital that the government takes action on poverty. We live in one of the richest countries in the world: we cannot have a society in which children are so damaged and disadvantaged.

title: coronavirus supermarkets could stay open
story: NewsCoronavirus: Supermarkets could stay open longer on Sundays in government planBoris Johnson confirmed he is looking at relaxing Sunday trading laws to let supermarkets open for longer than six hours - and a bishop has signalled the church could accept a changeShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBoris Johnson confirmed he is looking at relaxing Sunday trading laws" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSupermarkets could stay open for longer on Sundays as part of government plans to deal with coronavirus. Boris Johnson today confirmed he is looking at relaxing strict laws which govern how long shops can open for on the weekend.The Prime Minister said things could be done dferently and better, adding: Why not start being flexible  No details of any review, including when and how any changes could happen, have been confirmed. However, a senior bishop has signalled the Church of England could swing behind a temporary relaxation of the rules. Large shops such as supermarkets are banned from opening for longer than six hours on Sundays between am and pm. Longer hours have long been opposed by Tory MPs and religious groups - who say Sunday must be special for low-wage staff and small shops trying to compete.But the coronavirus crisis has led to an unprecedented demand at supermarkets, with long queues outside as fewer people are allowed in due to social distancing.Now there are signs the Church of England could accept a temporary relaxing of Sunday trading laws to boost the economy. Dr Alan Smith, The Bishop of St Albans, said the pandemic meant we must all think about innovative and flexible ways to protect our local economies. Dr Smith, who speaks on behalf of the Church in the House of Lords, told the Sunday : We have always wanted to protect workersapos mental well-being and it is clear having a day off in common with the rest of our communities is key to those protections. The opportunity for a day of rest for all workers to spend time with loved ones is a basic right. So, while the novel coronavirus means we must all think about innovative and flexible ways to protect our local economies, it must not be at the expense of workers.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has been in lockdown for six weeks.Hundreds of people are still dying each day from coronavirus. But now that we are past the peak, the government faces pressure to explain how, and when, it will ease up the rules. So over the next week, Boris Johnson is expected to lay out a roadmap for what will happen when the UK does relax the lockdown.He will change very little immediately - and wonapost end the lockdown in one go. But his plan will give us a clearer picture of what the UK will look like over the coming months in a new, coronavirus-scarred world. So what will reopen, what will stay shut - and how will your everyday le change  Weaposve had a look at the main proposals below.The aposroadmapapos explained The important thing to know is just because weaposre getting a aposroadmapapos this week, it doesnapost mean lockdown will end this week. The legal date to review the lockdown is Thursday  May, and Boris Johnson is expected to extend it for another three weeks, possibly with a few minor changes. But the PM will also - separately - announce a roadmap for easing the UK out of lockdown. This is expected later in the week, possibly only on Sunday  May. His plan will make clear that the UK is not ing to business as usual. Some restrictions will be eased, but others - like fines for breaches - will be made harsher than they are now. While people are put back on public transport and in some workplaces, there will be strict social distancing to keep people two metres apart. People are likely to be advised to cover their faces, and will be told to use an NHS phone app that alerts youyouaposve come into close contact with the virus.  When will it all happen  Thereaposs lots of speculation, but no firm date on when lockdown will start to be relaxed. As for when the current rules end completely, that may only be in . What we do know is the roadmap will begin once the aposRapos number - the average number of people infected by each Covid- carrier - is low enough. Currently R is . to . because so many people are out of contact with each other. Every time you relax a lockdown rule, R rises again. Ministers say they wonapost do anything that pushes the R number back above . The UK must also pass five tests before easing lockdown: The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPENo risk of a second peak that overwhelms NHS   Arriving in the UK Ministers are actively looking at quarantining people who arrive into the UK once lockdown begins to ease. Nothing is confirmed, but reports have suggested people will be asked to isolate themselves for two weeks. If so, this would be a major blow to the airline industry and render most holidays to Britain pointless. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps told the BBC: I think it’s important... that we ensure the sacrices in the sense of social distancing that we’re asking the British people to make are matched by anybody who comes to this country. So I am actively looking at these issues right now. So that when we have infection rates within the country under control, weaposre not importing.Schools Schools will reopen in a phased way, the government has confirmed - with some pupils going back first while others are told to remain at home. Ministers are looking at the idea of sending dferent year groups back at dferent times. Boris Johnson has signalled he wants primary schools to be the first to , while Walesapos First Minister has suggested Year  could be the very first year group back. Years  and  would then be the first back in secondary schools, according to one plan seen by the Sunday .  Priority could also be put on pupils with special educational needs. The Prime Minister must give schools notice in the next weekhe wants pupils tofrom June  - the first date head teachers have said could be acceptable. Schools say they will need time to put social distancing measures in place to ensure pupils are kept apart. Sources stress there is no final date and June may be put backthe virus is still too widespread. Universities The Sunday Times said at universities, arts students will be the last to , with students of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science prioritised in the autumn. Thirty-three universities are working on a contingency plan to fast-track students of the key sciences back to campus.  Public transport Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the number of trains will slowly rise as lockdown eases, to avoid overcrowding. Hand sanitiser and one-way systems would be placed on the network, with spacing at s and bus stops “clearly marked out” to keep people two metres apart. New timetables will be introduced as planned in May, even though trains will not run to them straight away. Firms would be urged to stagger workersapos start times to spread out the rush out. Meanwhile the government has hinted at more support for Cycle to Work, a tax break scheme where you can buy a bicycle over a year through your employer.  Workplaces and working from home Workplaces would have floor markings to ensure people are two metres apart, according leaked draft guidance. The guidance could also recommend staggered arrival times and breaks, fewer people in lts and regular deep cleaning, according to Sky News and the Sunday Express. However, it seems likely that not all workers would go back to the officethey donapost need to. Government advisors have previously said working from home could become the new normal until thereaposs a vaccine for coronavirus.Supermarkets Supermarkets would doubtless keep many of the social distancing measures theyaposve already put in place. And opening hours could be increased on Sunday to reduce overcrowding. Boris Johnson has said heaposs looking at relaxing Sunday trading laws to reduce queues on the weekend.  Picnics and going outdoors People will be allowed to exercise more than once a day, drive to the countryside and have picnics, according to the Mail on Sunday. Youaposd still have to be with members of your own household only, and keep two metres away from other groups.  No did not comment on the Mailaposs report. But ministers and scientists have repeatedly said outdoor gatherings look to be less risky than those indoors.  Building sites Building sites were never told to close under lockdown guidance - as long as two metres could be kept between workers. So the government is expected to make a renewed push for people toto work there. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said because the transmission rate of the virus outdoors is lower than indoors, there’s “more scope” for some jobs outside. He added: “Thereaposs more scope for people ing to work on building sites for example, or more outdoor leisure activities than is likely to be the case for indoor ones.”  aposBubblesapos of up to  peoplePeople could meet small bubbles of their friends and family under one idea to ease the coronavirus lockdown.Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish government was looking at the proposal as one possible way to relax restrictions on peopleaposs movement in the future. But she warnedthe idea does happen, itaposs got to be the same people day-to-day, week-to-week to prevent Covid- being passed on more widely. That means people would have to choose one bubble of friends or family - and stick with them, while continuing not to meet other people they love. Reports later said the idea was one being mulled by the UK government. But itaposs not set in stone.  Fines for breaching lockdown The government is considering raising the penalty for defying lockdown from £ to £ for a first offence. The fines would then double for each offence after that, just as they do already. And the maximum fine would rise from just under £, at the moment to £,. A senior government source did not deny these figures, reported by the Sunday , were under consideration. Covering your face The government hasnapost made a final decision on whether to ask people to cover their face in public. However, some kind of face covering advice is widely expected after Boris Johnson covering oneaposs face in some situations would be a useful tool. Itaposs understood thatface coverings are required, they wonapost be masks. The government doesnapost want to cause a shortage in personal protective equipment that should be available to the NHS. But coverings like a scarf could be recommended.And the government would provide guidance on what kind of material you can make such a covering from.Itaposs important that people donapost end up fiddling with their face covering in a way that means theyaposre actually creating more risk, by continually touching their face. Using a new app A new contact tracing app is expected to launch in around mid-May after trials on the Isle of Wight this week.The app, which is voluntary, will use Bluetooth to track when people have come into close contact with someone who, now or later, tests positive for coronavirus.It will urge someone who’s been in contact with a virus carrier to get tested and to isolate themselvesnecessary. It is part of the crucial “test, track and trace” strategy that is needed before the UK-wide lockdown can be relaxed. The idea is that this would allow society to partially reopen while keeping the virus at bay and sick people in isolation. For it to work properly, at least % or so of the population need to download it. It will be paired with an army of , human contact tracers to follow up on those who need further attention, or those who don’t download the app.  Pubs, grassroots sport, mass gatherings and other venues Pubs will be the last places to reopen as lockdown is eased, the Government has confirmed. Likewise, ministers have indicated that mass gatherings will be among the last things to reopen. But some local cricket and grassroots football could– as long as spectators can stay in the open air. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries said: “Outdoor environments are safer. Butyou go with a load of friends and sit in a pub… that’s not a good thing to do.”And Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick told the No coronavirus update: “Transmission is signicantly less outdoors than indoors.”Meanwhile hairdressers and nail bars could remain shut for six months, sources told The Sun. A aposone UKapos approach Scotland and Wales have repeatedly set out plans ahead of, or slightly dferently to, the rest of the UK government. And itaposs true that the Scottish and Welsh governments have control over areas like schools and care homes. However, ministers have also stressed they want to keep the whole of the UK moving in the same way at the same time. And the government has distanced itself from claims that worst-hit regions, like London and the West Midlands, could have dferent rules to the countryside. NHS services Some routine operations and fertility treatment have already been restored as hospital inpatients fall for several weeks in a row. However, itaposs not yet clear when other services - including ENT therapies and dentistry, where staff are particularly at risk of transmission - will continue.

Now Mr Johnson appears to have confirmed primary pupils could be the first to . The risk from Covid- is thought to be the lowest in the youngest children. The PM told the Sun on Sunday he wants primary schools reopened as fast as we can adding: Thataposs where we want to go. Itaposs about working out a way to do it. He said it “could be” at children with special educational needs or in Year  - who have the “rite of passage” of ending school - couldearlier than younger primary pupils. Asked about the idea she said: “I think a lot of ideas about rotation are being discussed, as we can see from other countries there doesn’t seem to be one obvious no-brainer answer.”  The Government is keen to get children back in the classroom as soon as possible to reduce the damage to aposearly years developmentapos and enable parents toto work. The two radically dferent properties only yards apart are both on the market. Business couple Mike and Jules Keen own Tindale Towers, an award-winning Art Deco mansion featured on Channel ’s I Own Britain’s Best Home. But it could just as easily appear on another C favourite – Rich House, Poor House. It has five bedrooms, a pool, a sauna, a gym, a badminton court, a dance floor, a bar for  people and a six-car garage. Other features include electronically-operated soft furnishings and self-cleaning glass. By contrast, a pebble-dashed two-up, two-down next to it in Bishop Auckland, Co Durham is worth barely more than the UK’s average yearly salary and is said to need “cosmetic upgrading”. The modest home has stood empty for some time and is thought to be owned by a London-based investment firm.   Now Mike and Jules, who own a furniture business but admit they need the money from the house sale, canapost wait to see which property goes first. Tindale Towers was put up for sale in  for £,, but the couple took it off the market.  Its new lower price tag is still well over three times the cost of the next dearest house currently listed by the same estate agents – and  times the £, average value of local homes.The agents’ blurb says all floors can be reached via an airy spiral staircase – or a lt. Mike, who says he is “skint”, said: “We’re still paying the bills but we’ve needed the money for a while. It’s a beautul house, it gives the town a good image.” The Keens built Tindale Towers  years ago on the site of their bungalow after buying an adjoining plot of land.  It was inspired by beach villas seen in France and Florida and named after Tindale Mill, where their business was first based. Major selling points of the house next door, which is described by agents as “an ideal investment opportunity”, include a feature fireplace and heat-resistant worktops.

title: couples swapped partners after karaoke
story: NewsCouples swapped partners after karaoke session - it was fast but it felt rightEXCLUSIVE: Heather Whitely and Darren Smith split up and and ended up with Peter Brettell and Susie Spencer, respectively. Here they tell how it all began with a karaoke session at the local bowls club...ShareCommentsByChantelle Rees:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSusie and Darren are living happily ever after after swapping couples" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhen two couples turned up for their local open mic night, they may have been thinking a duet was in the offing. What they didn’t know is that they’d both strike a chord with each other’s partners. Both couples then split up before the newly-single partners got together in a karaoke love swap. Heather Whiteley, , had been with Darren Smith, , for two years before they went along to the event at their local bowls club.Heather said: “I met Darren through Facebook. He was sweet, understanding and easy to talk to.“We were always up for a laugh so when we saw there was a karaoke evening being held at the bowls club, we agreed to go together. “I love a bit of karaoke and it sounded like fun.” While there they got talking to another couple – Peter Brettell, , and Susie Spencer, . Heather said: “We kind of knew Peter and Susie through the local community anyway. “They were involved in running a few karaoke nights and events locally. We had a great time that night, enjoying a sing-song and a few drinks together.” From that meeting in February last year, the two couples became friends, meeting a few times a week for a drink or a singalong session. Heather said: “We added each other on Facebook too and would chat on there. Susie and Peter seemed like a great couple. We weren’t super close, but we all got on well. “But in time, my relationship with Darren hit the rocks. We’d been ­having problems for some time but it took us a while to admit it.  “We were arguing all the time and eventually, in May , we split. “It was a really sad, dficult time, and I was still reeling from the break-up when I found out that Peter and Susie had ended their own relationship, too.” With both couples having split, Heather reached out to Susie’s former partner Peter. “I thought he might need someone to talk to,” she said. It turned out Heather had hit the right note.  “Peter wasn’t the type to talk about his feelings but he admitted he was ­struggling after his split from Susie.“And, as we got ­chatting, it ­became apparent wehad more in ­common than we thought.“We confided in each other. We realised we were the only ones who truly understood what we were both going through.” The pair became a shoulder for each other to cry on and soon began spending more time together. Peter said: “Susie and I had been together for two years but we were arguing a lot before we broke up. We just weren’t a team any more. “Darren knew Susie’s family through the karaoke nights. “We weren’t really close with Darren and Heather but we saw them in the pub quite often and would also chat on Facebook. “When all this happened, I turned to Heather for support.  “I don’t have many friends I can talk to about emotional stuff so when Heather asked meI wanted to talk, I opened up and it went from there. “She really listened to what I had to say and I wasn’t used to that. I felt I hadn’t been able to talk to Susie properly for months.” Heather added: “In time, Peter and I started to get close. I started to feel butterflies in my stomach for the first time in years. “It wasn’t long before we became a couple.”  Love Both pairs have since found lasting love after the karaoke carry-on. Darren and Susie are still together and Heather, who works as a home carer, and Peter, an events organiser, got engaged in September.  Heather, who lives in Winterton, near Scunthorpe, said: “It’s been a bit of a roller coaster but I don’t regret a thing because it led me to Peter, my true love.” And Peter added: “Heather and I got together around the same time as Darren and Susie. It was fast, but it felt right. “It was odd that we ended up ­together and so did they but, to be honest, they are welcome to each other because we are happier than ever.”

It is believed that planners had to come up with way round the problem and decided to simply build the road round it. Ken had been living there with his we, Beth, and their flock of sheep. A documentary, filmed almost  years after the motorway was completed, has revealed the truth about why the farm is in the middle of a motorway. Eleven years ago, Jill Falkingham bought the house along with her husband Phil, and the couple moved in with their son, John-William.
