title: tributes-paid-late-qc-activist-derek-ogg-65
story: Lawyers, politicians and campaigners came together on Saturday evening to pay tribute to Derek Ogg QC.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said he was a "truly lovely man" who "will be deeply missed by so many in his profession and beyond".The -year-old was found dead at his home in Rawclfe Gardens, Langside, on Friday evening.There are not thought to be any suspicious circumstances and his family have been made aware.:Glasgow law enforcement software firm in revenues hike and global expansionMr Ogg was a prominent campaigner for LGBTI rights from the s onwards, working to decriminalise sex between men and to remove discrimination from the law.In , the Equality Network charity presented him with a Letime Achievement award in honour of his contributions.During his y legal career he was appointed assistant principal advocate depute, one of the most senior positions in the Crown Office.He later became a defence lawyer and represented clients in a number of high-profile cases, while also acting as a legal commentator on current affairs programmes.The First Minister tweeted on Saturday: "This is dreadful news. Derek was a brilliant advocate and a truly lovely man."He will be deeply missed by so many in his profession and beyond."It was always a pleasure for me to hear from him on issues he felt strongly about, and I will miss his wisdom and good sense."His fellow QC at Optimum Advocates, Tony Graham, described Mr Ogg as a "fearless trial advocate, both as a prosecutor and as defence counsel".He added: "There was far more to Derek than his time in wig and gown."Whilst Derek was one of most well-read iniduals one could encounter, he was also a man who was full of fun, compassion and ready to assist anyone - colleague or not - in any way he could."He provided an ear to those who needed his wisdom, could put a smile on the face of the sullen, inspire a laugh from those engrossed in sadness, and create a conversation in even the solemnest of rooms.:Glen Gilson : Free legal advice to businesses seeking COVID emergency loans"Often, he did all of these things in a self-deprecating way."Gordon Jackson QC, deanof the Faculty of Advocates, said: "All of us who knew Derek Ogg are deeply saddened by his passing."He was a marvellous advocate but more than that he was a fierce campaigner for his beliefs both on a personal and professional level. He will be greatly missed by everyone at the faculty."Defence layer Aamer Anwar said he was a "beautul man of deep intellect, humility and humour".A Police Scotland spokesman said: "Around .pm on Friday May  , the body of a -year-old man was discovered by officers within a flat in Rawclfe Gardens, Langside, Glasgow."There would appear to be no suspicious circumstances surrounding the mans death and a report will be submitted to the procurator fiscal "The deceaseds family is aware of his death."

title: alistair-carmichael-its-now-time-consider-universal-basic-income
story: The world of work has changed a lot since then. Wages boards are a thing of the past. More people are self-employed. More work for agencies or on zero-hour contracts. Many small businesses which would previously been sole traders or partnerships have, instead, become limited companies.A great deal of this change has been spurred on through Government encouragement. The inability of governments to respond to the changes that they have created in recent decades means that our politicians now need to be bold and creative in how we respond. If we fail to do so then we risk leaving behind many of the hardest-working and most productive people in our communities. We also risk making the task of rebuilding our economy harder than it needs to be.That is why on Monday I urged the Chancellor of the Exchequer to look seriously at the idea of a Universal Basic Income. His response was dismissive but the growing calls in support of the idea are not going to go away.Thousands of families will face financial hardship in this crisis due to the current gaps in Government support. The small building firm in Shetland that I have been trying to help in recent weeks illustrates the problem well. It is owned by the two men who started it and runs as a limited company. The owners take most of their income though idends. Their four employees have been furloughed and their position ought to be secure. As things stand, however, there is no adequate help for the two owners of the business. The purpose of the furlough scheme is to protect jobs now for when productive work restarts. Unless we find a way of helping these business owners, and thousands like them, there will be no business to which the employees can .A few weeks ago I may not have been quite as dismissive of a universal basic income as the Chancellor has proven but I would certainly have been sceptical of its merits. Like most Scots I was taught by my parents that hard work would win reward, which would allow me to get on in le and then to pay back. It is how I have tried to live my le and how I, in turn, have raised my children. The idea of money coming from the government to every citizen, with nothing expected in , sits ill with that approach to le. Then again, the idea that government can close businesses, stop social and sporting gatherings and curtail our civil liberties in a quite drastic manner sits no more easily. We have all had to accept the necessary price of fighting this war against Covid-. Yes, a universal basic income risks giving money to people who do not need it. That, however, is something that is easily remedied through the tax system. If you think about it, we already have a form of universal basic income in the state pension. Anyone receiving that who gets more from an occupational or personal pension pays income tax on anything above the tax threshold. This also offers us an opportunity to gather evidence on which to base our decisions about the future of our economy and our society when this is all over. Income inequality has grown in this country and now poses a risk to social cohesion. A Universal Basic Income may be part of the answer to that. I frankly remain to be convinced but I have an open mind and I would like to see the evidence. Sir Arthur Conan Doylersquos most famous creation, Sherlock Holmes, put it thus: ldquoWhen you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.Our Government may not like the truth with which they are faced but they offer no alternative. If they continue in their failure to acknowledge reality, then they risk failing some of the people who are most deserving of their help. #Alistair Carmichael is a Liberal Democrat MP and former Secretary of State for Scotland

title: vicky-allan-feeling-burnt-home-school-home-work
story: def. exhausted or in poor health due to overworkThere have been many times over the past few weeks when itrsquos seemed to me that the much-talked of coronavirus slowness was a myth, or something Irsquod failed, personally, to grasp. At first I thought I was the only person feeling this, but then I started to realise many others were too. People I come in contact with kept telling me they felt more busy, not less ndash and Irsquom not just talking about key workers, but a wide demographic in terms of income and occupation. These people, of course, were mostly not those who had been furloughed or lost work. They were also, mostly, people who had kids.Last week, this paper reported that millions of people forced to work from home ldquomay be at risk of burnout as their work-le balance is turned upside down. It may seem hyperbolic for us to talk about feeling burnt out by just the mere challenge of trying to work and home-school our children, but therersquos a pace of le for many of us here thatrsquos undoubtedly unsustainable. Irsquom waking at am to get time to work before home school starts, and Irsquove talked to many others stretching out their days, doing their double shts.We may be moving around less, but many of us are as busy. When our cars, trains, planes and workplaces stopped, tech rushed in ndash Zoom, Microsoft Teams, streamed talks and events ndash and not just for us, but also for our children. On Facebook this week I found myself joining in on a thread, started by a parent with a small business, who complained that she was struggling to get to grips with the confusing system of online school assignments being sent out to her kids.It echoed my own feelings that one of the biggest challenges of the recent weeks had been to try to work out what my eldest son, at secondary school, is expected to do. He wants to manage it himself, but it seems unmanageable. Work arrives on dferent s ndash via email, Teams, website downloads ndash with assignments often not where you expect them to be.Reports into lockdown delivery of online education are revealing a staggering dference between inidual schools, and crucially between the state and private sector. Neil Mackay, writing in this paper last week, reported that a survey by the Scottish Secondary Teachersrsquo Association before Easter found that less than half of children were engaging with teachers. He described how one teacher had told him she only had four children out of  join an online lesson. I recognise that. My son was one of three in such a low turn-out class and only because we happened to spot the message when it came in.And I understand why kids arenrsquot engaging. It feels to me asour childrenare being thrown in at the deep end and the swimming skills they have to learn are a form of digital self-management. Some may emerge at the end having learned practices of self-organisation, but many will not. Some, in some houses, have no access to digital learning at all. Irsquom not blaming the inidual teachers, many of whom are locked in a struggle of trying to deliver learning through new technology s, while also possibly juggling their own kids. I also think itrsquos wrong to blame parents. The wider system itself should deliver a lot better for all kids.I also, however, think that children are part of a wider world, and above all we need to be working out right now how to make this better for all of us in the new normal.The truth is Irsquom someone who believes in slowness. I take on board Danny Dorlingrsquos argument that evidence shows we are already going through a period of technological slowdown, economic deceleration and declining growth.But it feels aseven in this pause, le for many of us is only getting more digitally hectic. We could resist that ndash let our kids get bored and drop out at work ndash but most of us are still struggling to earn and the answers to many of our current problems demand work. They also require rethinking whatrsquos important ndash and, what with home school and homework, many of us are too busy for that.Feeling wakeful  The Covid pandemic, a recipe for insomniaVicky Allan is feeling grateful. How coronavirus is showing us a new gratitude

title: celebrating-500-miles-road-brought-prosperity-plaudits
story: The majestic scenery should easily sell itself ndash rolling mountains, sandy beaches fringed by rocky clfs, historic castles, eerie plains and isolated villages.Yet for years, Scotlandrsquos northern coastline was either simply too far away, too much trouble to reach, with apparently nothing to do and just not well enough known about for many tourists to bother with.That, of course, was before the arrival of Scotlandrsquos biggest tourism phenomenon, a simple but devastatingly effective marketing masterstroke which has brought an unprecedented visitor boom to some of the nationrsquos most remote nooks and crannies.Launched in  in the hope it might boost Scotlandrsquos struggling northerly communities, the North Coast  has raced past the likes of Americarsquos Route  to be regularly named among the worldrsquos greatest road trips and a bucket list ldquomust do for people around the world.Five years on, what began as a hopeful plan to throw a spotlight on Scotlandrsquos lesser visited northern coast has put small communities, rollercoaster single-track roads, once almost deserted campsites, restaurants and hotels on the tourist map almost all year round.Now, with international tourism in tatters and the thoughts of many turning to when lockdown might be eased, there is every likelihood more Scots than ever before may well follow the lead of tens of thousands of visitors who have already explored the -mile route.Tom Campbell, Chairman of NCand who came up with the idea of a north coast touring route, says the ldquoseismic change in how Scots and other UK nations holiday as a result of Covid- could result in a staycation boom, helping to ensure the success of the NC and businesses along the route continues through dficult times.ldquoAirline holidays are going to be more expensivethey are even possible, he says. ldquoI think wersquoll see more UK visitors heading to Scotland and driving will be the way people will want to take their holidays.ldquoThe NC is ideally suited to that. The open spaces, the fresh air and all the things that make the route special havenrsquot changed ndash the seascapes are still there, the landscape is still amazing, the food from sea and land, and the infrastructure is still there.ldquoCovid- has meant we have had to hit the pause button, but all the reasons that made NC the number one route in the world have not changed.The NC winds its way north from Inverness to Dornoch, Wick and Dunnet Head, traversing the roof of Scotland before twisting and turning its way along the west coast and crossing back to its starting point.Travellers could simply plot their own course around the routersquos scenic attractions, but many opt to become paid-up members of the NC travel ldquoclub, giving them precious access to inside information and advice to make their experience more enjoyable.An overwhelming number of tourists who complete the route give it a giant ldquothumbs up ndash % according to the routersquos  visitor survey. What began as an initiative to bring some fresh opportunities to the area was last year estimated to have boosted the economy by pound. million and created around  full-time jobs.For businesses, travellers in their cars, campervans, motorbikes and even cycles have brought unexpected prosperity. Room occupancy for hotels and bed and breakfasts has soared from around % to around % ndash in some places even higher ndash with room rates almost doubling in price. Attractions from distilleries to museums, restaurants, shops, campsites and castles have all reported giant leaps in visitor numbers.Yet, as Campbell points out, the routersquos incredible success wasnrsquot entirely expected. ldquoWe launched in May  with a spring in our step ndash we had an audience reach of , at that point. By , that audience had grown to . billion, he adds.Along the way have been key moments that have embedded the route into the minds of prospective tourists around the world. ldquoNot for a minute did I imagine that Aston Martin would one day approach us and askthey could create a new DB limited edition around the NC, adds Campbell.ldquoOr that Jeremy Clarkson would describe it as lsquothe best route in the worldrsquo and that the journey from Ullapool to Gairlochrsquos scenery was so spectacular thatThe Melvich Hotel by Thurso has been a spot for travellers to rest since the s.But, like many businesses along its -mile route, the launch of the NC five years ago has transformed it from what had been a far-flung destination for a few hardy travellers.ldquoIt used to be we got older couples with time and money to spend on travelling, says Jo Wyke, who runs the hotel with husband, Robert.ldquoThe NC has breathed new le into the area, people are realising there is a lot to do and wersquore seeing dferent kinds of visitors, people looking for adventure, surfers, people who want outdoor sports.ldquoWe were getting people from all the world, and starting to see visitors from India, the Far East, China, Russia and Latin American countries.ldquoThe last couple of years have been record-breakers for us which is down to the NC.

title: surrogate-mums-left-holding-baby-covid-19-rules
story: The first cuddle and the journey home for a new le together are among the most precious first moments of parenthood.However, couples who have spent years planning to become parents via a surrogate pregnancy are now facing the heart-breaking reality of missing priceless early moments of their babyrsquos le.Social distancing rules and Covid- lockdown have left parents-to-be facing a nightmare scenario of not being able to be close by for their babyrsquos birth, and even raised the complex issue of how they might meet their precious newborn and bring them home.Meanwhile, tight restrictions over hospital visits to maternity wards could also leave surrogate mothers facing the dilemma of having to care for the baby ndash with all the potential emotional conflict that might bring ndash or refusing to look after it at all.It could lead to babies being handed over in car parks and laybys or, worse, placed in the care of social services or foster parents while efforts are made to unite them with their intended parents.The situation has led to calls for social distancing rules to be relaxed so at least one intended parent can be allowed into maternity wards during the birth and throughout the babyrsquos hospital stay.One Edinburgh couple awaiting the birth in August of their first child via a Sunderland-based surrogate said their hopes of being able to savour precious moments of being with their baby straight after birth have been thrown into disarray by the pandemic.ldquoWe donrsquot know what will happen when baby is born, said Kevin Doebrich, who with husband Chris Kelly has been preparing for parenthood for three-and-a-half years.ldquoIf we are still under lockdown, we wonrsquot be allowed to go to hospital for the birth.ldquoWe are hearing from others who are having a baby now that what happens is very much on a case-by-case basis.ldquoSurrogacy is fairly rare and with everything going on in hospitals just now, itrsquos not a high priority.The couple have hired a private midwe amid hopes that their surrogate, Linder Wilkinson, , can have a home birth. However,strict lockdown rules are in place, there could be a question of whether even travelling from their Edinburgh home to Sunderland to collect their baby will be outlawed.ldquoEverything depends on what happens with the baby nearer the time, and whether it will have to be a hospital birth, added Chris. ldquoWe will deal with whatever the situation is. We are just looking forward to being parents.NHS trusts across the UK also have strict rules restricting scans, antenatal appointments and classes to just the pregnant woman, leading to concerns that intended parents are missing key moments and information related to their baby.Instead, Chris, , and Kevin, , are relying on videos filmed by their surrogate Linder which show their baby kicking and making recordings of themselves reading stories to be played to the growing baby so it becomes aware of their voices.ldquoThe key thing from day one has been that Linder is healthy and the baby is healthy, added Kevin. ldquoMissing the -week scan was disheartening and we were sad, but also ecstatic. We are just trying to crack on.Under normal circumstances, maternity wards allow intended parents to spend time in hospital after the birth enabling the surrogate ndash although legally the infantrsquos mother ndash to have no role in its care.However, there are fears surrogate mothers may now feel pressured to take over caring responsibilities such as feeding, bathing and nappy changes, and to make decisions over the babyrsquos care while waiting to be discharged.Linder, who has previously delivered surrogate babies to two other couples, said: ldquoI understand the reasons for restrictions, but there is a need to make an exception.ldquoThe baby will have two parents who are willing to look after it. I have no biological link with the baby and Irsquom not prepared to provide care for the baby ongoing, because itrsquos not right for me to do that.She added: ldquoIrsquove heard of surrogates having to look after the baby until they are discharged. Irsquove also heard of hospitals allowing the surrogate to be discharged while a parent goes in to look after the baby until it is ready to leave, which is much better. Itrsquos really important that Chris and Kevin can be there and have those first moments with their baby.There are also concerns that the legal processes which pass on full parental rights may be delayed due to Covid-, potentially leaving families in limbo for months.Olivia Rowlands, , whose womb was damaged by bowel cancer treatment which also sparked early menopause, and husband Sam, , from St Andrews, have also had their hopes of attending their babyrsquos birth thrown into confusion.Ellie Hutchinson, , from Stirling, Oliviarsquos cousin, is due to give birth to the couplersquos daughter by planned caesarean section in July.Olivia said: ldquoWe really donrsquot know what will happen during the birth.ldquoWe had hoped we could both be there ndash I canrsquot imagine not being able to see Samrsquos face when our baby is born. Wersquore not surethat will be possible.ldquoAfter the birth is a really tricky part. Ellie really wants Sam and I to be the ones who look after our daughter as soon as shersquos born and we want this to be as easy as possible for her.ldquoOn paper, Ellie is the legal mum. I canrsquot imagine the doctors saying I canrsquot be there and making Ellie look after the little one. Wersquore trying to be optimistic and positive.Meanwhile, couples at an earlier stage in their surrogacy journey who have invested years of planning and thousands of pounds on medical and legal procedures have also seen their dreams of parenthood stalled by a rules surrounding IVF and fertility treatment.Stuart Young, , and partner Gordon Anderson, , are currently waiting for an egg donor. Stuart said: ldquoWe donrsquot really know how long a delay this will cause, we are at the mercy of the rules stopping all fertility treatment.ldquoSurrogacy is incredibly complicated and complex with rules and regulations that we have had to learn about.ldquoWe had already resigned ourselves to the fact it would take a while. We just donrsquot want to be in our mid-to-late s and still be in this position.ldquoWe would love to be parents, itrsquos a dream we both have and we just have to focus on what we want.

title: rons-spotlight-however-view-creation-great-britain-no-doubt-violently-opposed-majority-scots
story: The days opened with the bells of St Giles Cathedral ringing out on May the First in , legally uniting Scotland and England as the Act of Union came into force. The tune the bells played was at the very least ambivalent about the newly-forged connection, Why Should I Be Sad On My Wedding Day.Well, maybe, although the hostility to the conjoining is underestimated. However you view the creation of what was to be Great Britain there is no doubt it was vigorously and violently opposed by the majority of Scots.Riots in Edinburgh and other Scottish towns in the months and years leading up to it had become a feature of everyday le. The Duke of Hamilton, who led the nationalist opposition , was cheered along the Royal Mile as he passed each day in his carriage, whereas the Duke of Queensberry, who supported the deal, required round-the-clock protection from hostile mobs chucking not just epithets but anything they could lay their hands on.When Daniel Defoe arrived in the city in  in his day job as an English secret agent, he described ldquoa Scots rabble is the worst of its kind, while conceding that ldquofor every Scot in favour of the union there were  opposed.Scotland had been all but bankrupted by the Darien scheme to build a colony on the plague-afflicted isthmus of Panama although as most of the population had nothing to lose, their level of poverty remained as crushing and deadly as it had before. It was the nobles and rich speculators, who had gambled and lost in the mad venture, who were hustling it through on the promise of a better time, mainly for themselves as they were to receive more than half of their losses ed.The Edinburgh parliament represented Scottish opinion only in a theoretical sense, made up as it was of self-perpetuating noblemen and landowners, but this was true of all parliaments wherever they existed. By the eve of the Union there were  parliamentarians, some  hereditary peers,  "shire" or county commissioners, and  burgh commissioners.The rough head count at the time reckoned that the majority of the parliament would be agin the deal, which is where blatant bribery was employed to buy votes and pay spies and agents provocateurs, pound, sterlingof which was distributed by the Earl of Glasgow.As Robert Burns famously put it, ldquoSuch a parcel of rogues in a nation they were ldquobought and sold for English gold.By then, the Scottish and English thrones had been united under one monarch for more than  years, since the Union of the Crowns in , when James Vl also became king of England when Queen Elizabeth died childless.James was Mary, Queen of Scots son, although he hadnrsquot seen her since he was an infant. The doomed Mary, taking advantage of May Day, wassailing and general drunkenness in Lochleven Castle where she was being held a prisoner in , managed to escape and head south. She was heedless of her advisers telling her not to go to London and she ended up, of course, heidless.May , eight years earlier, had seen theof John Knox from exile to lead the Scottish Reformation. And as Gandhi would probably have said had he been around to be asked: ldquoI think that would be a good idea.Knox believed that having a woman ruler ndash as he blasted in his famous tract The First Blast of the Trumpet against the monstrous regiment of women ndash was a violation of the natural order. Following Maryrsquos escape from Lochleven he joined the chorus condemning Mary as an adulteress and murderess and for the rest of his le spoke of her as ldquothat wicked woman.May  in  was also the day the King James Version of the Bible was published in London.There have been monsters throughout Scottish history, usually of the two-legged kind. On May  in  while one of most evil in history was starting a reign of terror on his people by first taking over German trade unions, here we were looking to the north of the country and Loch Ness, not to Hitler, and the legend of the serpentine monster began.There may have been local mutterings and sightings before but when the Inverness Courier ran a story about a large ldquobeast or ldquowhale-like fish it was christened Nessie. The writer was Alex Campbell, a water bailf on the loch and part-time journalist, and the article covered an alleged sighting by Aldie Mackay of an enormous creature writhing about the water as she and her husband drove along the shore.In Campbellrsquos words, ldquoThe creature disported itself, rolling and plunging for fully a minute, its body resembling that of a whale, and the water cascading and churning like a simmering cauldron. Soon, however, it disappeared in a boiling mass of foam.Not for long, however, because it was to reappear with regularity in the years that followed, to be photographed ndash although some of the shots were hoaxes or genuine misinterpretations of innocent logs and waves ndash and see surveys and expeditions camp on the shore for months, and to be written about until this day.The latest "sighting" was in  when Apple Maps showed a satellite image of what appeared to be a -metre-long monster, although it might just have been the wake of a boat, ripples caused by seals or floating wood.On that same day in , a monster capable of both destroying the world and powering it opened in southwest Scotland. It was the Chapelcross nuclear station on a former Second World War airfield near Annan, commissioned to produce weapons-grade plutonium for the UKrsquos weapons programme and also to generate power for the National Grid.The plant was decommissioned in  but the final demolition and site clearance wonrsquot be complete until at least , but more likely the new century. Hope yoursquore around for that.On May  in , the first Hillman Imp rolled off the production line at the new Rootes factory at Linwood. It was meant to compete with the highly-successful Mini, but it was hastily designed and badly executed. It was rear-engined and handled badly ndash some customers placed a bag of cement under the front bonnet to keep it stable ndash and it had an inadequate cooling system, gearbox and clutch problems, faulty chokes and a tendency to leak water. No surprise the Imp developed a reputation for unreliability.It wasnrsquot all bad as it provided work in an industry-ravaged area although that was not to last and, in , the company donated  Imps, painted green and white, for Celtic fans to drive to Lisbon to watch their team lt the European Cup.After  years it was over ndash ldquoLinwood no more as the Proclaimers sang in Letter From America ndash when Chrysler, which had taken over from Rootes, closed the factory and, in its words, put an end to that ldquodamned poorly-designed automobile. And damned the , or so who were directly or indirectly employed by the company to the dole queue.Another carmaker, Henry Ford, said that history is bunk. The future isnrsquot looking so bright either.

title: talking-rabbish-right---new-laws-land
story: In particular, Irsquod suggest three measures to be strictly enforced by police officers properly primed by watching The Sweeney and other procedural shows from the halcyon days when informal beatings were an essential part of criminal investigations.The first measure relates to my one-person campaign against horticultural racket. Irsquove no idea why this remains a one-man campaign. Am I the last person on Earth with ears, or at least a degree of sensitivity Well, Irsquom here to give the racketeers an ear-bashing, though first Irsquod better rsquofess up: I myself have an electric Flymo and I know how to use it. Irsquove tried ious hand-propelled mowers and theyrsquore all rubbish. Flymo gets the job done quickly, or ought to. Irsquove heard folk spend three hours with them on lawns the size of postage stamps.The strictures on mowers will also apply to electronic or petrol-driven trimmers, strimmers, bishers, bashers and boshers. Some folk seem unable to do anything unless itrsquos driven by electricity or petrol. Irsquom sure I saw, though it may have been in a dream, electric nose-pickers in BQ.Worse even than horticultural hellishness are DIY drills, piercing the air and driving up the blood pressure of all around. Itrsquos true. Reported this week, a study by German researchers found exposure to racket can cause long-term health implications, not just high blood pressure but potentially also cancer.No wonder. In many city suburbs and country villages, the racket is relentless. Well, itrsquoll have to relent.Under my measure, the racketeers will be allocated what theyrsquoll no doubt consider Happy Hour in which to make a daily din: say  to pm, extended maybe to  to am and  to pm on Saturdays nothing at all on the Sabbath. Failure to observe this restriction will result in one day of imprisonment for every minute of racket.Before coming to my second democratic authoritarian measure, on a related horticultural matter Irsquom also advocating that people with gardens who donrsquot appreciate them, except as racket-zones, should be moved into flats.Similarly, many country people should be relocated to urban council housing schemes, where theyrsquoll be happier among their own sort, listening to rap and making a hullabaloo.My second measure involves the confiscation and destruction of any time piece costing more than pound. I was appalled ndash becoming my default state ndash to read about Good Morning Britland presenter Ben Shephard sporting a series of fancy watches, the cheapest costing pound, and the dearest over pound,.This is disgraceful. On that manrsquos wrist is a device costing more than three times an unemployed personrsquos annual benefits. Well, soon, Big Ben will be forced to watch his luxury gewgaws being ground into the dust by properly trained goons in hi-vis jackets.My third liberal authoritarian measure will outlaw spitting. This splashed onto the news agenda with talk of the resumption of football, where the practice is re.Well, soon, any player expectorating can expect to be gobsmacked by a three-match ban. Theyrsquoll have to swallow their pride along with whatever other glutinous agglomeration apparently accumulates periodically in their gobs.I trust such inhumane but necessary measures will enjoy popular backing though I suspect that, as usual, mine will be a voice howling in the wilderness ndash whereupon someone will open a window and tell me to keep the noise down.Stay home foreverHATE to say it but those of us who work from home and never get holidays are now able to say to the rest of you: ldquoSuck it up, you suckers. Now you know what itrsquos like.Sadly, however, the holiday market is preparing itself for theof normality, loosely defined. For many young persons, itrsquos a trip to Spainrsquos ldquoparty islands where, under normal, flaky circumstances, much drink would be consumed by holidaymakers wearing shorts and other louche leisure apparel.Personally, Irsquod regard such holidays as a punishment, but maybe thatrsquos just me again: Irsquove never knowingly got into the party spirit. My idea of hedonism is a family bag of Revels.The unfortunate risk for revellers is that the firms currently offering bargain hols from  June onwards wonrsquot be refunding doshthe lockdown is still continuing by then.Irsquom happy to provide a public service and reiterate the advice of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office: ldquoWe advise against all but essential international travel. That is excellently put, and we must hope the advice remains for ever, with the omission of the words ldquobut essential.FIVE THINGS WE LEARNED THIS WEEKTHE skies are getting bluer. Prof William Collins of the University of Reading says the recent reduction in traffic pollution has left skies looking their natural colour: deep, tropical blue. There you are: every cloud has a silver lining.THIS year sees the ,th anniversary of the Battle of Thermopylae, where  Spartans held outagainst  million Persians. The event is still studied by military strategists today, with many concluding the  should have legged it.THE citizens of ancient Pompeii were keen recyclers, according to US archaeologists. Rubbish was reused for filling earth floors and other building work. Pity the poor folk never got the chance to put volcanic ash in the right recycling bin.METEOROLOGISTS have discovered the earliest reliable written record of somebody being killed by a meteorite falling on their heid. Manuscripts in Turkish archives reveal a bloke was killed in Iraq in . What are the chances, eh  One in , apparently.A STUDY by American researchers found that over-s were best prepared for the collapse of civilisation. They were most likely to have stockpiled food, water, a torch, candles, battery-powered radio, and first aid kit. Wot, no jigsaws Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: virtually-perfect-scots-gardeners-turn-new-leaf-online
story: The camerawork can sometimes be a tad shaky, there may well be occasional interruptions from the cat and the commentary might be a little bit breathless.But, having been denied the chance to show off their gardens for public viewing this spring, some of Scotlandrsquos best amateur gardeners have laid down their trowels and discovered new skills as film makers to showcase the dazzling fruits of their labours for us all to enjoy at home.Using rarely touched cameras, carefully picking their way down their garden steps, tiptoeing across immaculate lawns and zooming in to show off delicate blooms, gardeners across Scotland have created homemade versions of Gardenersrsquo World.As a result, their delightful short films are providing a peek at normally hidden blossoming back gardens, giving locked down viewers with nothing  to do but wonder what to do with their own back yard, much-needed real le inspiration.The private gardens captured on film by proud owners are among hundreds which had been due to throw open their gates to the public this spring and summer under Scotlandrsquos Garden Scheme.Normally the event is a chance for visitors to wander by dazzling floral displays, water features, fruit and vegetable patches and lovingly tended shrubs infor a charity donation.Lockdown, however, has meant the scheme, which has run every year since , had to be cancelled.Faced with hundreds of gardens at their blooming best with no-one but their owners to enjoy them, the organisers of the scheme suggested gardeners might head outside with mobile phones to capture their gardens now and in the weeks to come, both to keep the fundraising going and to bring naturersquos glory to viewers stuck indoors.Now the first efforts have been uploaded each offering a charming insight to the loving care green-fingered owners have poured into their outdoor space, as well as inspiration for anyone with a typical back garden ndash wheelie bins and all - crying out for plants but not sure where to start.ldquoSince  our charity has been successfully running open days every single year, even during WWII, but this stopped in March this year, says Terrill Dobson, the Director of Scotlandrsquos Gardens Scheme.ldquoAnd even though the gardens are looking splendid and people are seeking solace in gardening, our Garden Openers will not be able to welcome visitors for the foreseeable future.The Schemersquos call for videos has seen new videos arriving almost daily.ldquoGarden Openers genuinely want to share whatrsquos happening in their gardens while hoping to support the charities that now need it even more than ever. We ask people who would have come to the gardens to watch the videos and consider a donation.Of course, few watching may feel they can instantly achieve the heights of David Gallacher and Tom Williamson from Bonnyrigg. Their short video takes viewers around their ft by ft garden which is crammed with around  dferent plants,  containers and pots and  hanging baskets in a ft x ft area.Or, on a completely dferent level, the stunning garden at Shepherd House in Inveresk, East Lothian. Filmed by its owner, artist Lady Ann Fraser, viewers are taken on a leisurely stroll past calming water features, sculptures, vibrant flowers spilling over borders, clinging to arches and lining paths.Some gardeners taking part in whatrsquos been dubbed the lsquovirtual gardenrsquo scheme, have revealed expected talent as film makers, offering running commentaries of garden design, plant choices and gardening tips.In the case of Chris and Jerry Gregson of Greenbank Crescent in Edinburgh, filming involved negotiating steep steps and trying to avoid camera shake while chatting about how theyrsquove created terraces of colour.ldquoWe had to learn how to use the camera, says Chris. ldquoWersquove made two films, and now wersquore being asked to make more because people want to see what happens next in the garden.ldquoSometimes I canrsquot even see what Irsquom taking a picture of because the sun is in my eyes, so Irsquom pointing the camera and hoping for the best!In Stirling, Stephen Kellyrsquos short film shows how he has covered the back garden of his home in a typical modern estate with hundreds of jewel-coloured tulips. Standing tall in pots, borders and beds, they create dazzling splashes of colour and earned his home the name, the Tulip House.Best of all for would-be gardeners feeling overwhelmed by the thought of how to create their own floral extravaganza, he points out how simple they are to grow. ldquoIf yoursquove got some pots, fill them with soil, stick in some bulbs and yoursquore pretty much guaranteed to succeed.Meanwhile Jean Knox filmed her garden in Hunterrsquos Tryst, Edinburgh, despite efforts of her black and white cat, Tosh, to photobomb her efforts.ldquoHe likes to be with people, andI donrsquot engage with him, hersquoll just plant himself on the ground and roll over, she says.For would-be gardeners currently contemplating their own wilderness, she confesses her immaculate garden with its herbaceous and shrub beds, fruit, water features and seating areas, was once in chaos too.ldquoEverything in it now, I have done from scratch, she adds. ldquoI suggest people start with a masterplan and try to create their garden around what they want to use it for.For gardeners yet to find their green fingers, there is some comfort: ldquoIrsquove wasted a fortune over the years and I still make random purchases from the garden centre, she adds.ldquoIt often comes down to finding a place where a plant is happy and leaving it there.To watch the videos, visit Scotlandrsquos Garden Scheme at www.scotlandsgardens.org.

title: david-pratt-pandemic-press
story: In the absence of pub quizzes during these days of social distancing, herersquos a question to ponder.In which current global table does Norway come out on top and North Korea find itself in bottom place Most of us hazarding a guess at the answer would likely say it had something to do with human rights, and that assertion wouldnrsquot be far off the mark.The answer is, in fact, the  World Press Freedom Index, compiled by the media watchdog, Reporters Without Borders, better known by its French acronym .As someone who has spent the last four decades of his le working in journalism, every year I examine the data compiled in the index with a degree of trepidation. Its main purpose is to evaluate the situation for journalists in  countries and territories across the globe.In this regard therersquos no doubt the index has become an extremely useful advocacy tool in helping promote free, independent and pluralistic journalism and in defending media workers rights.But vital as such a role is, this serves as little consolation to the fact that the conclusions drawn by the index these past few years have been far from heartening. The current index is no exception, or then again perhaps it is, for rarely in recent times has it portrayed a bleaker picture of the threats facing media freedom worldwide.Those threats, of course, have inevitably been amplied by the coronavirus pandemic, as existing and aspiring autocrats around the world crack down on journalistsrsquo ability to do their jobs at a time when transparency is more vital than ever.In fact, so pressing are those threats that RSF has warned that the next  years will pretty much determine the fate of journalism as we know it. ldquoWe are entering a decisive decade for journalism linked to crises that affect its future, says RSF secretary-general Christophe Deloire. ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic illustrates the negative factors threatening the right to reliable information, and is itself an exacerbating factor, Deloire added in his recent summation of the current index ratings.Questioning what all this means for freedom of information, pluralism and reliability by , Deloire maintains the answer to that is already being determined and as we move through this ldquodecisive decade, five converging crises are having a malign influence and potentially devastating impact on international journalism.The first of these is what RSF says is a ldquogeopolitical crisis due to aggressiveness of authoritarian regimes, which coronavirus has already starkly highlighted.The second is a ldquotechnological crisis resulting from the lack of appropriate regulation of digitalised communication, creating a kind of ldquoinformation chaos blurring the lines between fact, fiction, propaganda and advertising, often putting them in direct competition with mainstream bona fide journalism.The third crisis in this perfect storm facing journalism highlighted by RSF is a growing physical hostility towards journalists globally.Much of this hostility, it concludes, is an offshoot of the hatred towards the press fomented by some political leaders such as US President Donald Trump and his counterpart Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil.ldquoHostility toward journalists and news outlets in the US deepened and intensied, and few attacks were as vitriolic as those that came from the president, the media watchdog concluded.ldquoThe abuse is only getting worse amid the coronavirus pandemic in , as journalists covering the Trump administrationrsquos response to the crisis are subjected to the presidentrsquos attacks during his press briefings, it added.According to the index ratings, the US now ranks th out of  countries. A ldquodangerous anti-press sentiment as well as the arrest, physical assault, public denigration and harassment of journalists had trickled down to the local level in America, the report determined.Related to this open hostility and the last of the five elements in the crises press freedom faces is one of trust, says RSF. Or put another way the public suspects broadcast and print news to have been contaminated by unreliable information.In making its case for this, the media watchdog cites a recent Edelman Trust Barometer conducted by the US-based public relations group that studies public trust in institutions.According to those polled in Edelmanrsquos latest international survey, % of people believed the media they used were contaminated with information they thought untrustworthy. That in itself, most would admit, is cause for serious concern, but combined with the other threats outlined, all five converge into one enormous challenge to the worldwide press of the future.Itrsquos a sobering thought not least today, May , as we mark World Press Freedom Day along with its theme this year of ldquojournalism without fear or favour.In order to understand in real terms just what these threats mean to journalismrsquos future, itrsquos worth drilling down a little deeper into their implications.The obvious place to start is with the impact of the pandemic itself. Having said that, long before the emergence of coronavirus, world press freedoms were recognised as being in decline.For many years journalists have weathered authoritarian regimes and threats to their safety. But where most observers are now in near total agreement is that the pandemic has brought a new dynamic to the media landscape exposing the long-term risks of suppressed press freedomsAs Robert Mahoney, deputy executive director of the Committee to Protect Journalistspoints out, those countries that stle independent news and jail journalists in ldquonormal times have already been hard at work.In what some journalists have called the global ldquoCovid crackdown, China and Iran, th and rd respectively in the Press Freedom Index, tried to quarantine the truth. In Iranrsquos case the leadership there censored news of its spread with devastating consequences for public health.Many media monitoring groups are now concerned that, for the most part, governments have been getting away with their efforts to impede independent journalism without being called out by other countries, all of which are also preoccupied in dealing with the pandemic.ldquoGovernments in Thailand, through Hungary and Egypt to Honduras, are using the cloud cover of the diseases to introduce emergency measures that could roll back basic freedoms, clamp down on the press, or restrict foreign correspondents, warned Mahoney of the CPJ recently on Al azeera.At its worst this manests itself in arrests, detention, intimidation, physical threats and sometimes murder.In terms of Covid--related reporting, human rights group Amnesty International last week highlighted a handful of cases where reporters have been prosecuted or threatened. Among them was that of Russian journalist Elena Milashina whose newspaper Novaya Gazeta on April blished an article in which she criticised the Chechen authoritiesrsquo response to the pandemic.Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov in turn posted an Instagram video in which he threatened Milashina, appealing to the Russian government and Federal Security Serviceto ldquostop those non-humans who are writing and provoking our people. In Egypt, meanwhile, security forces arrested Atef Hasballah, the editor-in-chief of AlkararPress newspaper on March , and subjected him to enforced disappearance for nearly a month, following a post on his Facebook page in which he challenged the official statistics on Covid- cases.In Venezuela, it was journalist Darvinson Rojas who spent  days in detention after reporting on the spread of the virus in the country and was pushed by authorities to reveal his sources.These are only three of many instances globally where reporting on the pandemic brought journalists under threat, but itrsquos not only during the current crisis that such measures have been documentedLast year,  serious threats to press freedom were recorded, including  physical attacks on journalists. A total of  cases of intimidation and direct threat have been listed in a report compiled by several media organisations, among them RSF, the Association of European Journalists and the International Press Institute.Late last year, too,  journalists were imprisoned for their work, primarily in Turkey, Russia, and Azerbaijan.As Otmar Lahodynsky, president of the Association of European Journalistswrote recently in the EU affairs newspaper NewEurope, the takeover of media by oligarchs and governments in Hungary, Poland, and Serbia were also noted and criticised in the report.ldquoMany public-service broadcasters have been turned into uncritical propaganda channels for the government. Abuses of media freedom are also increasing in Western Europe, says Lahodynsky, adding that political influence on the media is increasing in many of the  countries that count themselves as members of the Council of Europe.But beyond these obvious threats to journalism and its future lie others, many economic, with job cuts gutting newsrooms. As RSF makes clear, the digital transformation has brought the media to their knees in many countries.Falling sales, the collapse in advertising revenue and the increase in production and distribution costs have in turn forced news organisations to restructure and lay off journalists.ldquoThe economic crisis has also accentuated the phenomena of ownership concentration and, even more, conflicts of interest, which threaten journalistic pluralism and independence, warns the watchdog.The bottom line here is that global journalism currently faces both old threats and new, raising the inevitable question of how best to protect and nurture its existence in the ldquodecisive decade that lies ahead.According to Farhana Haque Rahman, senior vice-president of the global news agency Inter Press Service, ultimately, just as in a pandemic, the freedom of the press can only be guaranteed by a co-ordinated global effort and a focus on highlighting the long-term advantages of a more critical world.ldquoThis means pressure to reinforce legal frameworks, including prosecuting harassers and killers, perhaps just as the international community would persecute war criminals, while offering a global protection for journalists, says Rahman.ldquoFinding and promoting innovative ways of subsidising independent media, as well as getting big tech companies to pay for the content they share, is also crucial to help a free press to thrive, she says.Just as the response to the coronavirus pandemic has been described as a marathon not a sprint, so must the long-term future of journalism be viewed in the same terms.Ever since the United Nations proclaimed World Press Freedom Day on this date back in , the obstacles facing independent reporting have consistently been immense.Censorship, smear campaigns, harassment, intimidation, arrest and detention, threats of physical assault and murder are the challenges journalists across many parts of the world have had to contend with.These are unprecedented times and, as one colleague recently observed, no working journalist alive has ever covered anything like this story of the pandemic. Even veterans of war reporting or Ebola coverage have had to re-evaluate risk and learn new skills.As we mark World Press Freedom Day itrsquos obvious that many challenges beyond the current one lie in wait. Most likely these will put the very heart of journalistic practice and the ability to carry it out without fear or favour to an unprecedented test.To say we need journalism now more than ever is true. But it also masks a reality worth reiterating, one that makes clear the importance of having a free press each and every day, whether the story is of global or local concern.In either instance, holding power to account and performing a public interest role is fundamental to this. But just as the press holds the powers at be to account, so too do we need reasoned critical consumers of the media, those similarly capable of holding the media to task for any misrepresentations of the truth.It was the great French author and journalist Albert Camus who once observed that: ldquoA free press can of course, be good or bad, but most certainly without freedom, the press will never be anything but bad.If, as the World Press Freedom report suggests, the next  years prove to be an unprecedented test for the media, then good journalism will need all the allies it can muster.As RSF secretary-general Christophe Deloire, rightly pointed out: ldquoFor this decisive decade to not be a disastrous one, people of goodwill, whoever they are, must campaign for journalists to be able to fulfil their role as societyrsquos trusted third parties, which means they must have the capacity to do so.Speaking as someone with a vested interest in that happening, I can only say how welcome that trust would be. But equally, however, those within my profession must realise that in order for that to take place, we too must prove ourselves worthy of that same trust.

title: britain-begin-post-brexit-trade-deal-talks-us-week
story: The government is looking to strike an ambitious relationship, which will open up new opportunities to businesses in Britain.International Trade Secretary Liz Truss and US trade representative Robert Lighthizer will launch the negotiations via video conference call because of the Covid- crisis.Around  negotiators on each side will take part in the talks, the first round of which are set to last for a fortnight.Further rounds will take place roughly every six weeks, and will continue to be carried out remotely until it is safe to travel.:Refusal to extend Brexit transition period raises chilling prospect of no-deal, warns Ian BlackfordMs Truss said: ldquoThe US is our largest trading partner and increasing transatlantic trade can help our economies bounce back from the economic challenge posed by coronavirus.ldquoWe want to strike an ambitious deal that opens up new opportunities for our businesses, brings in more investment and creates better jobs for people across the title: neil-mackay-strange-saga-scotland-spies-special-forces
story: Ken McCallum took over the Security Service just a few weeks ago ndash only the second time a Scot has led the UKrsquos domestic spying organisation. The last Scottish MI chief was Sir David Petrie, director general during the Second World War.They are two very dferent men ndash reflecting the changing nature of our spying services. Petrie was born in Inveravon, Banffshire in , and studied at Aberdeen University. Friends described him as a ldquorugged and kindly Scot hellip with immense physical and moral strength.He started out as a colonial policeman, serving in the Indian Imperial Police from  to . Petrie ran MI when it was being tested in the crucible of the fight against Nazism. He retired in , ladened with medals.McCallum is a middle-aged mathematician from Glasgow who has been at the heart of some of the biggest terrorist and spying sagas of recent years.He graduated from Glasgow University in  with a first-class honours degree. He has been in MI for almost  years. For the first  years, it was Northern Ireland which occupied his time, and he played a major role in the Ulster peace process. He then moved into countering Islamist terror, and specialising in cybersecurity.McCallum led on counter-terror during the London Olympics. He has also focused on fighting far-right extremism. In , McCallum headed the MI investigation into the poisoning of Sergei Skripal. He is also interested in how machine learning can aid spying. However, we know little about his private le, apart from the fact hersquos a dad and likes hill climbing.It is a mistake to think these two men are all Scotland has had to offer when it comes to great spies, though. Petrie and McCallum are just the tip of the iceberg. Scotland has a long, dark and fascinating history of espionage.When it comes to spies, itrsquos always the people who most fascinate. Why did they become spooks  What did they do  So, letrsquos start with the characters who have dominated Scottish spying over the years.THE AGENTSThe Jacobite turncoatMeet Pickle the Spy ndash otherwise known as Alastair Ruadh MacDonnell, th chief of the Clan MacDonell of Glengarry. Herersquos a man whose le could have jumped from the pages of an adventure yarn.As a boy, McDonnell, a Catholic, was sent to France to finish his education. While there, the Jacobite leader John Drummond, Duke of Perth, raised the Royal-Ecossais regiment, made up of exiled Scots. MacDonnell was commissioned a captain.In spring  MacDonnell was sent back to Scotland to meet Jacobite chiefs. He was eventually captured, though, and sent to the Tower of London. Not long afterwards his brother was killed after the Battle of Falkirk.He was recruited as a double agent by Henry Pelham, then British Prime Minister. Released under the  Act of Indemnity, he was soon working as the infamous spy codenamed Pickle. Information from MacDonnell helped secure the arrest and execution of the Jacobite leader Archibald Cameron, who had escaped into exile after Culloden.MacDonnell is thought to have pocketed the infamous treasure of Loch Arkaig, otherwise known as the Jacobitersquos Lost Gold. During the  rebellion, over a million French and Spanish gold coins were shipped to Scotland to assist the Jacobites. In the confusion of war, it ldquovanished and Archibald Cameron was dispatched to Scotland in  to find the money.His other mission was the assassination of George II. While on the hunt for the missing gold, double agent Pickle betrayed him, and Cameron was hanged, drawn and quartered. Legend has it that MacDonnell claimed the missing loot and drted into retirement.The Scot whofought the SovietsROBERT Bruce Lockhart was a typical Scottish son of the Empire. Born into a prosperous Fe family of teachers, he waseducated at Fettes College and then left for Malaya to run rubber plantations. His taste for adventure was soon plain. He ran off with ldquothe beautul ward of a Malay prince, but later caught malaria and had to recuperate back in Britain.He joined the Foreign Service and was posted to Moscow. A talented footballer, he joined a local team which won the Moscow League championship in . Come the  Revolution, Lockhart was British Consul General, eventually becoming the UKrsquos first envoy to the Bolsheviks.He was now sleeping with the we of a Russian count, who was also a suspected Soviet agent, and working for British intelligence. He was given pound million in diamonds to fund a Russian agent network. In , Lockhart and Sidney Reilly ndash aka The Ace of Spies ndash were accused of plotting to assassinate Lenin. Later, he was confined in the Kremlin as a prisoner but escaped trial in a spy swap. The Soviets later sentenced him to death in absentia.His autobiography Memoirs Of A British Agent became the  Hollywood movie British Agent, starring Leslie Howard. During the Second World War he co-ordinated all British propaganda against Nazi Germany. His son, Robin Bruce Lockhart, wrote the book Ace Of Spies which became a TV series starring Sam Neill in the s. He died in  after struggling with alcoholism most of his le.Oor ain Jane BondSCOTLAND had its own female version of Indiana Jones working as a spy ndash Lorraine Adie Copeland, half archaeologist, half Jane Bond hellip and her son turned out to be Stewart Copeland, drummer in the band The Police.Born in Scotland in , Copeland came from a wealthy family ndash her father was a neurosurgeon with offices in Londonrsquos Harley Street.Highly intelligent and well educated, during the Second World War she was recruited by the Special Operations Executive. SOE ran espionage and sabotage missions in occupied Europe. She met her husband at this time, the famed American spy Miles Copeland, described as charming and charismatic.The pair married in  and Copeland was soon involved in espionage in Syria, Lebanon and Egypt. It was while she was in the middle east that she began studying archaeology, eventually becoming a world expert on the Stone Age.Friends remember her as highly outspoken. The couple were friends with Kim Philby, Britainrsquos most notorious double agent, a member of the Cambridge spy ring who worked for the KGB while a senior MI officer. In Beirut, the Copeland home ndash the site of many glamorous parties ndash was known as ldquoThe CIA House.What better couple to work as international spies ndash a beautul, intelligent Scot, and a handsome, dashing American.They could have been characters in an Ian Fleming novel. She died in  at her French home, taking her secrets to the grave.Scotlandrsquos spy for Imperial JapanNOT all of Scotlandrsquos spies are charming rogues or brilliant beauties, some are just sleazy traitors. Step forward William Forbes-Sempill, the th Lord Sempill. Born at Craigie Castle in Aberdeenshire, he was educated at Eton before joining the Royal Flying Corps at the outbreak of the First World War. He was one of the most successfulairmen of the conflict.However, his fame and glamour were a cover for something much darker. In , he led a British mission to Japan to help develop its airforce. However, when the Anglo-Japanese Alliance ended in , Sempill should have cut all military contact with Tokyo.He didnrsquot. He began passing classied information in exchange for money. When MI tapped his phone, they discovered his manservant was a Japanese sailor.There was a risk thatSempill was interrogated, Tokyo might work out that Britain had cracked Japanese codes. It was decided it wasnrsquot in Britainrsquos best interests to prosecute him.However, itrsquos also pretty clear his position played a big part in saving his skin ndash his father was aide-de-camp to King George V. Unbelievably, Sempill went on to work at the Admiralty, with access to secret information.By , it was clear that Sempill was also pro-Hitler ndash and still spying for the Japanese. Churchill believed that when details of his own personal movements were intercepted on their way from the Japanese Embassy to the Tokyo Foreign Ministry, Sempill was involved.By autumn , Churchill proposed getting rid of Sempill by offering ldquohim a post in the north of Scotland. However, come Pearl Harbour in December , Sempillrsquos offices were raided and secret documents uncovered which shouldnrsquot have been in his possession.It was clear evidence of treason, but again no prosecution followed. Sempill agreed to retire from public office and died in .SPYLANDIT isnrsquot just people who have made their mark on the art of spying when it comes to Scotland ndash itrsquos the landscape itself, ideally suited to training spooks, saboteurs and assassins.Special Operations Executiveused Scotlandrsquos wild Highland terrain to train agents during the war. SOE had around  camps in secluded locations across the country. One site, in Inverlair in Inverness-shire, known as ldquoThe Cooler, was used to house agents who had either failed training or been recalled from duty.The Cooler was meant to provide time to decompress, and to ensure anyone unstable didnrsquot leak sensitive information.The north of Scotland was also useful for infiltrating Nazi spies due to its remote coastline. One of Hitlerrsquos top agents, Vera Eriksen ndash the German Mata Hari ndash was snared at a Buckie railway station.She had landed by boat nearby. Eriksen was found, along with fellow agent Karl Drucke, with a kne, pistol, money, a radio and a list of RAF bases. Another pair of Nazi spies was caught in Scotland because they were cycling on the wrong side of the road.SOE used Arisaig House for Commando training Glasnacardoch Lodge at Mallaig was a weapons cache and firing range Drumintoul Lodge in Aviemore and Glenmore Lodge in Inverness-shire were used for training commandos to fight in occupied Norway Achnacarry Castle was a general commando training facility and Belhaven School, Dunbar was used to train wireless operators behind enemy lines.Unsurprisingly, then, the SAS was founded by a Scot ndash David Stirling, who was born in Lecropt, Perthshire in  into a wealthy, well-connected military family.He studied at Cambridge and dreamed of becoming an artist in Paris. At over six feet, he was training to climb Everest when the Second World War broke out.Commissioned into the Scots Guards, he then volunteered as a commando in the unit known as Force Z.He eventually persuaded top brass to allow him to set up an experimental special operations outfit designed to operate behind enemy lines. Stirlingrsquos right-hand man was Jock Lewes, the SASrsquos principal training officer and inventor of the Lewes Bomb.Stirling led from the front. His men would drive through German aircraft bases in North Africa shooting up planes and setting off explosives. In one raid, they took out  aircraft, mostly bombers, with just one man lost.Stirling, who was dubbed ldquoThe Phantom Major by Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, was captured by the Germans in . He escaped, was recaptured and sent to Colditz. Field Marshall Montgomery described Stirling as ldquomad, quite mad, but believed men like him essential to winning the war.After the war, Stirling set up a mercenary outfit. He was linked to a failed coup against Libyarsquos Colonel Gaddafi. He later established an organisation called Great Britain  ndash made up of aristocrats and ex-soldiers ndash who planned to take over the running of the UK in the event of civil unrest and government collapse. Stirling also worked to undermine trade unionism.The flawed father of British special forces died in .SPOOK CULTUREITrsquoS little wonder then that the current series of SAS: Who Dares Wins finds a natural home in Scotland. Itrsquos filmed on Raasay. In its latest bizarre outing, celebrities like Katie Price and Joey Essex are put through special forces training while being humiliated by retired SAS operatives.Of course, therersquos a slightly more upmarket side to Scotlandrsquos spooks on film and in literature. Without Scotland, the spy genre would be a shadow of itself. Richard Hannay is the prototype fictional spy hero.A creation of the Scottish author John Buchan, Hannay made his first appearance in the  thriller The Thirty-Nine Steps about German spies operating in Britain in the run-up to the outbreak of the First World War.The plot mirrored real attempts by the Kaiser to use spies in Scotland to gather naval intelligence. Hannay, who is also Scots, appeared in six more novels, and is based on Edinburghrsquos Edmund Ironside, a spy during the Boer War.He was later prosecuted in  under the Official Secrets Act for his wartime autobiography Greek Memories. He pleaded guilty to avoid trial and prison. The book revealed that UK embassies were used as spy cover, named the section of British intelligence which we now know as MI, and revealed that the head of MI was known as C.Of course, C is the inspiration for the fictional spymaster M in the James Bond novels. Not only was Bond played most memorably by Sean Connery, but  is also a Scot. In the novels, Bondrsquos father is Andrew Bond from Glencoe. After a brief stint at Eton, Bond gets expelled ndash for hanky-panky with a maid, of course ndash and completes his education at Fettes.There are echoes of Bond in the le of his creator, Ian Fleming. Fleming had a Scottish father ndash Valentine, a Tory MP from Newport-on-Tay in Fe. Flemingrsquos grandfather was the Scottish financier Robert Fleming.And, of course, in a neat full circle, the latest Bond movies shot some of their most iconic scenes in Scotland, with Skyfall filmed around Glen Coe and Glen Etive. The upcoming Bond movie No Time To Die also features stunning action sequences shot around Badenoch.So, the long and strange love affair between Scotland and spies continues into the future.

title: kim-jong-un-not-undergo-surgery-south-korean-officials-claim
story: North Korea had said on Saturday that Mr Kim attended the completion of a fertiliser factory near Pyongyang on Friday, in his first public appearance in about  days.While his re-emergence, captured on video footage released by North Korean state media, quelled intense rumours that he might be gravely ill or even have died, some media outlets and observers still raised questions about his health, citing moments when his walking looked a bit stf at the factory.A senior South Korean presidential official told reporters on Sunday that the government has determined that Mr Kim did not have surgery or any other procedure, according to the presidential Blue House.When rumours about Mr Kimrsquos health surfaced in recent weeks, the South Korean government steadfastly dismissed them as baseless and maintained there were no unusual activities in the North.It is not the first time Mr Kim has disappeared from public view for an extended period.In , when he reappeared after a six-week absence, he walked with a cane and used an electric cart.The North Korea-provided footage on Saturday showed the -year-old riding an electric cart similar to the one he used in , when he was reported to have an ankle injury.In , Mr Kim entered talks with President Donald Trump on the fate of his nuclear arsenal, but their diplomacy has been deadlocked in recent months.Mr Trump tweeted on Saturday that ldquoI, for one, am glad to see he is back, and well!
